description.he: מזבח הזהב, הידוע גם בשם "מזבח הקטורת", משמש להקטרת (שרֵפת) קטורת. מקום המזבח הוא בתוך היכל המקדש.

description.en: The Copper Altar (Mizbeach Hanechoshet) is the altar upon which sacrifices and libations are offered. The Copper Altar is located within the Temple compound but outside the shrine itself.
description.he: מזבח הנחושת הוא המזבח המשמש להקרבת קורבנות ונסכים. מקומו של מזבח הנחושת במתחם המקדש אך מחוץ להיכל עצמו.
לפני בניית המקדש בירושלים עמדו בבתי אב רבים ובמקומות אחרים מזבחות, שנקראו גם "במות". הבמות שימשו להקרבת קורבנות ומנחות, אך השימוש בהן נאסר לאחר בניית בית המקדש, שרק בו רוכזה עבודת הפולחן.
description.en: Prior to the construction of the Temple in Jerusalem, many homes and other locations had altars, or bamot, that allowed for sacrifices and other offerings. After the Temple was built, however, these altars — both private and public — were prohibited as ritual was centralized.

A mezuzah is the small parchment placed inside a case and attached to the right side of entryway doorframes where Jews reside. Written on the scroll are various sections from the Torah, such as the [Shema](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/shema?tab=sources), that feature some of Judaism's central principles.
description.he: המזוזה היא נייר קלף קטן הנמצא בתוך נרתיק (בית המזוזה) המחובר לצד הימני של משקוף הדלת בבתי יהודים. על מגילת הקלף כתובים מגוון קטעים מן התורה, דוגמת פרשת שמע הכוללת כמה מהעקרונות העיקריים של היהדות.

description.en: The Chanukah Menorah is called a Hanukkiah and is a candelabra with nine branches. It is lit in homes and synagogues during Chanukah to commemorate the miracle in which one day's worth of oil for the Temple Menorah burned for eight days.
description.he: מנורת חנוכה קרויה חנוכייה, והיא למעשה מנורה עם תשעה קנים. את החנוכייה מדליקים בבתים ובבתי הכנסת בחג החנוכה כדי להזכיר את הנס שהתחולל בחנוכה: פך השמן האחרון שנותר במקדש אמור היה להספיק להדליק את המנורה ליום אחד בלבד, אך באורח נס הספיק לשמונה ימים.

description.en: Ma'aser Sheni (Second Tithe) is a second tithe taken from produce in Israel during the first, second, fourth, and fifth years of the seven-year cycle. As opposed to the other tithes, it is kept by the owner on condition that he eats it in Jerusalem.
description.he: מעשר שני הוא תרומה הנלקחת מעשירית היבול החקלאי בארץ ישראל בשנה הראשונה, השנייה, הרביעית והחמישית במחזור של שבע שנים. בניגוד לתרומות אחרות, המעשר השני נשמר אצל בעליו כדי שלבסוף יאכל אותו בירושלים.

description.en: The mikveh is a pool (literally, a “gathering”) of water from a natural source. While the Temples stood, to gain entry into the Temple, to partake of certain sacrifices, or for a couple to be intimate — among other reasons — Jews tried to maintain a status of ritual purity. While there are different kinds of ritual impurity and as many processes to regain a status of ritual purity, immersion in a mikveh, a ritual bath, is an important element in the purification process. Today, the practice of immersion in a mikveh is used to mark life transitions, conversion to Judaism, to ready oneself for Yom Kippur, before birth, and as a central element in the observance of the laws of niddah (the practices surrounding menstruation, intimacy, and ritual purity).
description.he: המקווה הוא בריכה ריטואלית המכילה מים ממקור טבעי (דוגמת מי גשמים). הטבילה במקווה נעשית לשם טהרת אנשים הנחשבים טמאים לפי ההלכה, וכן היא משמשת בתהליך הגיור.

description.en: The Mishkan (in English, Tabernacle) was the temporary, portable Temple that the Jews were commanded to build after the revelation at [Mount Sinai](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/mount-sinai?tab=sources). It had all of the furnishings of the future Temple and served the same functions, but it was smaller and used fabrics and animal skins for its walls and roof.
description.he: המשכן היה המקדש הנייד והזמני שבני ישראל הצטוו לבנות אחרי ההתגלות בהר סיני. המשכן והמקדש מילאו את אותו התפקיד וכן שימשו בהם אותם הכלים, אך המשכן היה קטן יותר וקירותיו וגגו היו עשויים עורות ובדים.

description.en: Candles (nerot) — or any type of clean-burning oil lamps — are an important feature in the celebration of Shabbat and Jewish holidays. The main function of candles is to provide light in the home at night in order to enhance the festive atmosphere. Candles are also key to Temple and Chanukkah rituals.
description.he: נרות הם מאפיין חשוב בציון שבתות וחגים. הם משמשים להארת הבית בלילה כדי להשרות אווירה חגיגית על הבית. נוסף על כך הנרות ממלאים תפקיד בטקסים של בית המקדש וחג החנוכה.

description.en: A sukkah is a temporary hut that is covered by organic material, such as tree branches, that serves as a dwelling during the week-long holiday of Sukkot. During Sukkot, Jews typically eat, socialize, and sleep in the sukkah instead of inside their permanent homes.
description.he: סוכה היא מעין בקתה המשמשת למגורים בשבעת ימי חג הסוכות. לסוכה חייבות להיות לפחות שלוש דפנות, ואת הגג שלה יש לבנות מחומרים אורגניים כגון ענפי עצים. במשך ימי החג נוהגים היהודים לאכול, לישון ולבלות את זמנם בסוכה במקום בבתי הקבע שלהם.

description.en: A Torah Scroll (sefer torah) is a copy of the Hebrew Bible that is written by hand on parchment according to various rules in order to ensure its accuracy, readability, and holiness. The Torah Scroll is primarily used in synagogue during Jewish prayer services, including on Shabbat.
description.he: ספר התורה הוא העתק של חמשת חומשי התורה שנכתב בידי אדם על קלף (נייר העשוי מעור בעלי חיים). כתיבת הספר חייבת להתבצע על פי כללים שנועדו לשמור על הדיוק, על הקדושה ועל קלות הקריאה של הספר. בספר התורה נעשה שימוש בבתי הכנסת בזמן התפילות, כולל בשבת.

description.en: A Parah Adumah, or Red Heifer, is an unblemished and completely red cow that has never been put to work. The animal’s ashes are used to purify someone who has come into contact with a corpse.
description.he: פרה אדומה היא פרה שצבעה אדום לגמרי ללא רבב, שמעולם לא שימשה למלאכה. אפר הפרה האדומה משמש לטהר את מי שבא במגע עם אדם מת, הנקרא "טמא מת".

description.en: Tzitzit are the ritual fringes added to four-cornered garments. Four strings are threaded through each corner and folded over and knotted in order to produce eight fringes. Ideally, three of the strings should be white and the fourth should be azure, which is known as tekhelet in Hebrew.
description.he: ציצית היא השם הכולל לחוטים שיש להוסיף לבגדים בעלי ארבע פינות. בכל אחת מן הפינות משחילים ארבעה חוטים, מקפלים וקושרים אותם עד שנוצרים שמונה קצוות חוט בכל פינה. שלושה מהחוטים בכל פינה צריכים להיות לבנים והרביעי בגוון תכלת מיוחד.

description.en: Incense (Ketoret) was offered daily on the Golden Altar in the Mishkan and Temple, and its ingredients are dictated in the Torah. There are also mystical properties associated with it, as seen from its use in protecting Jews from God's wrath in the desert (Num. 17).
description.he: בכל יום התבצעה הקטרת (שרֵפת) קטורת על מזבח הזהב במשכן ובמקדש. מרכיבי הקטורת נזכרים בתורה. בקטורת נקשרו תכונות מיסטיות מסוימות, כפי שעולה מהשימוש בה בהגנה על בני ישראל מפני מגפה שהביא עליהם אלוהים (במדבר יז).

description.en: The Mincha Offering (Korban Mincha) was the daily afternoon sacrifice of fine flour with olive oil and frankincense that was offered upon the Copper Altar in the Mishkan and in the Temple.
description.he: קורבן מנחה הוא קורבן מן הצומח המורכב מקמח מנופה, שמן זית וסולת. המנחה הוקטרה מדי יום אחר הצוהריים על מזבח הנחושת במשכן, ולאחר מכן במקדש.

description.en: Libations (nesekim) are liquid offerings placed upon the Copper Altar that generally consist of wine and olive oil. On Sukkot, water is also used.
description.he: נסכים הם קורבנות נוזלים המועלים על מזבח הנחושת. בדרך כלל הם מורכבים מיין ומשמן זית, ובסוכות גם ממים.

description.en: The Omer Offering (Korban HaOmer) consisted of a measure of barley that was brought to the Temple on the second night of Passover, which coincides with the barley harvest in Israel. Then, 49 days are counted until the wheat harvest, which is known as “Counting the Omer.”
description.he: קורבן העומר הוא קורבן משׂעורים שהובא למקדש בלילה השני של פסח, תאריך המסמל את תחילת קציר השעורים. הבאת הקורבן פותחת את "ספירת העומר" – ספירת ארבעים ותשעה הימים עד ליום התחלת קציר החיטים.

description.en: Shabbat candles — nerot shabbat, in Hebrew — are used in the sanctification and celebration of Shabbat. The two candles symbolize the commandments to observe and remember the Sabbath, and they provide light in the home at night to enhance the atmosphere of Shabbat.
description.he: נרות השבת משמשים לקידוש ולחגיגת השבת. שני הנרות מסמלים את הציווי הכפול של השבת – "זכור ושמור", וכן מאירים את הבית בלילה כדי להשרות בו אווירת שבת חגיגית.

description.en: The shofar is made from the horn of an animal, usually a ram. In the Bible, the shofar was blown as a trumpet in battle and, today, is used primarily during Rosh Hashanah services and at the end of Yom Kippur as a “wake up call” to repentance or to announce God the King.
description.he: את השופר מכינים מקרן של חיה, בדרך כלל אַיִל. בעבר שימשה תקיעת השופר לתרועה בעת קרב, אך כיום השימוש העיקרי בשופר הוא בתפילות ראש השנה וכן בצאת יום הכיפורים, אז התקיעה מסמלת מעין "קריאת השכמה" לקראת השנה העברית החדשה.

description.en: Oil features in various contexts in the Jewish textual tradition. In the Bible, oil is used to anoint kings, High Priests, and vessels of the [Tabernacle (mishkan)](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/mishkan?tab=sources), as fuel for the [Menorah](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/menorah1?tab=sources), and in various biblical stories. Oil also features as an element in food, cosmetics, medicine, and sacrifices, among other functions.
description.he: ברוב המקרים השמן המוזכר בתנ"ך הוא שמן צמחי, ובייחוד כזה המופק מזיתים. השמן מילא תפקיד בפעולות רבות במסורת היהודית, אך השימוש העיקרי בו היה חומר בעֵרה למנורה שבבית המקדש.

description.en: Mixtures (taaruvot) of permissible and forbidden substances are a subject of much discussion and debate in Jewish law. Different criteria are used to decide whether there is a sufficient amount of a forbidden material to render a whole mixture forbidden.
description.he: תערובות הן כינוי כולל למוצרים או לחומרים מותרים ואסורים שהתערבבו יחד. לאורך השנים שימשו דיני תערובות כר פורה לדיונים ולמחלוקות בהלכה היהודית. כמה קריטריונים נועדו לקבוע אם כמות החומר האסור בתוך התערובת מספיקה כדי לאסור את התערובת כולה.

description.en: Tefillin are black leather boxes that contain small parchment scrolls on which specific passages from the Torah are written. Tefillin are worn on the upper arm and forehead, usually during morning prayers, except on Shabbat and holidays, as the means of fulfilling the commandment to "bind them as a sign on your hand and as a symbol between your eyes" [(Deuteronomy 6:8)](https://www.sefaria.org/Deuteronomy.6.8?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en).
description.he: תפילין הן קופסות עור שחורות ובתוכן מגילות קלף של פסוקים מן התורה. יהודים מגיל בר מצווה מניחים את התפילין על הזרוע ועל המצח מדי יום חול לפחות פעם אחת ביום החל בתפילת שחרית.

description.en: Terumah is the tithe, or heave offering, taken from produce in Israel and given to the Kohanim, or priests.
description.he: תרומה היא מתנה מקודשת הנלקחת מן היבול החקלאי בארץ ישראל וניתנת לכוהנים.

description.en: The menorah was a large candelabra with seven branches located within the Temple shrine in Jerusalem. The menorah was lit and cleaned by the priests every day. The menorah used on the holiday of [Chanukkah](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/chanukkah?tab=sources) is called a chanukkiyah, and it has nine branches.
Tekhelet is a dye used in ritual fringes, the tapestries in the Mishkan (Tabernacle), and the clothing of the High Priest.

categoryDescription.en: Narrative moments in Tanakh and Talmud.

description.en: Marah, meaning bitter, was a place in the Sinai that the Israelites reached in their wandering. They couldn't drink the water there because it was bitter until Moses performed a miracle to sweeten it.
description.he: מרה הוא מקום במדבר סיני, שבו עברו בני ישראל במסעותיהם. המים במרה לא היו ראויים לשתייה משום שהיו מרים, ומשה המתיק אותם במעשה נס.

description.en: The Prayer of Abraham was his plea to God not to destroy the evil city of Sodom. This was a manifestation of his great loving kindness towards all people, which brought him to challenge God about His intentions there.
description.he: תפילת אברהם היא פנייתו של אברהם לקב"ה שלא יחריב את סדום, עיר הרשע. תפילה זו היא עדות לחסדו של אברהם כלפי כל העמים, שהובילה אותו לקרוא תיגר על כוונותיו של הקב"ה.

children.en: Abraham in Ur Kasdim and his Departure from There
God's Blessing and Promise to Abraham
Destruction of the Land of Israel

description.en: The destruction of the Temple can refer to the destruction of either of the two Temples that stood in Jerusalem in the ancient period. The First Temple, built by King Solomon, as described in the book of I Kings, was destroyed in 586 BCE by Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon. The Second Temple, built approximately 70 years after the destruction of the first, was destroyed in 70 CE by the Roman Empire.
description.he: חורבן בית המקדש, או בקיצור ״חורבן הבית״, הוא מושג המתייחס לשני אירועים היסטוריים - חורבן בית המקדש הראשון בשנת 586 לפני הספירה על ידי נבוכדנצר מלך בבל, וחורבן בית המקדש השני בשנת 70 לספירה על ידי טיטוס - קיסר האימפריה הרומית. לעיתים, המושג ״חורבן הבית״ מתייחס באופן נרחב יותר לאיבוד עצמאותו המדינית של עם ישראל בארצו בתקופות אלו. בעקבות החורבן, תיקנו חז״ל 4 ימי תענית: עשרה בטבת - בו התחיל המצור על ירושלים בבית ראשון, י״ז בתמוז - יום ביקוע חומות ירושלים, תשעה באב - הצום העיקרי בו חרבו שני בתי המקדש וצום גדליה - בו נרצח גדליה בן אחיקם אשר היה הנציב היהודי בירושלים לאחר חורבן בית ראשון.

description.en: Stories of the world's creation appears in the first two chapters of the book of Genesis. Generations of Jewish thinkers have spilled much ink analyzing the meaning and significance of these chapters.
Egyptian decree against newborn sons.

The Garden of Eden features in the opening chapters of the book of [Genesis](https://www.sefaria.org/Genesis?tab=contents). God plants the garden, causes trees to grow there, and places Adam in the garden to work and preserve it. After [Eve and Adam](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/adam-and-eve?tab=sources) eat forbidden fruit, God drives them out. The Garden of Eden has been the subject of analysis and discussion throughout thousands of years of the Jewish textual tradition.
The Davidic lineage.

children.en: Appointment of Judges for The Generation of the Desert
Edom and the Generation of the Desert

description.en: Shortly after the giving of the Torah at Mount Sinai, despairing that their leader Moses had died atop the mountain, the Israelites built and began to worship a golden calf — in direct violation of the first commandments of the [Ten Commandments](https://www.sefaria.org/Exodus.20.3?lang=bi&aliyot=0). The "golden calf" may refer to either the idol the Israelites built or [the narrative](https://www.sefaria.org/Exodus.32?lang=bi&aliyot=0). Upon Moses' discovery of the Israelites' grievous transgression, he smashed the tablets of the law, ground up the golden calf, and made the Israelites drink the mixture.

The twelve spies feature in the books of Numbers and Deuteronomy. They were a group of leaders - one from each tribe - sent by Moses to scout the land of Canaan ahead of the Israelites arrival there. They came back reporting that the land was good, but that it was filled with giants and fearsome enemies. This prompted the Israelites to cry and complain that they did not want to enter the land. Two of the twelve spies, Joshua and Caleb, attempted to assuage their fears and remind the people of God’s commitment that the Israelites’ would enter the land.

children.en: Stopping of the Sun in Gibeon
Borrowing the Property during the Exodus from Egypt
Retributions during the Exodus from Egypt

description.en: The Exodus from Egypt is a story described in the Book of Exodus, in which the Israelites’ are miraculously freed from enslavement in Egypt through ten plagues and the splitting of the Red Sea. The holiday of Passover commemorates these events, and discussing the exodus is a focal point of the Passover seder.
description.he: יציאת מצרים היא סיפור המתואר בספר שמות בתנ״ך, שבמהלכו יצאו בני ישראל באופן ניסי משעבודו של העם המצרי. הניסים המרכזיים המתוארים בסיפור הם עשרת המכות ששיאם במכת בכורות, וקריעת ים סוף אשר אפשרה לעם ישראל לברוח מהצבא המצרי לכיוון ארץ כנען. חג הפסח מהווה זיכרון ליציאת מצרים, וההגדה של פסח, אשר אותה קוראים בליל הסדר, דנה בהשתלשלות האירועים.

children.en: Crossing the Jordan River and Setting of the Stones

description.en: Journey of the Ark in the desert.

The Tower of Babel refers to a narrative presented in [Genesis 11:1-9](https://www.sefaria.org/Genesis.11.1?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en). The story describes how people attempted to build a city and tower, the top of which would reach the sky. God confounds their speech and scatters them, ending the project. The story has been the subject of much analysis and discussion throughout thousands of years of the Jewish textual tradition.

children.en: Moses and the Tent of Meeting

description.en: Meribah is a place mentioned in the books of Exodus and Numbers. In one story in Exodus, the Israelites complain about a lack of water. God instructs Moses to hit a rock; Moses does, and water comes out. The place is then called Massah and Meribah, commemorating the incident. In a similar story described in Numbers, God instructs Moses to take his staff and talk to a rock after the Israelites complain about a lack of water. Moses hits the rock twice and water comes out. God then tells Moses and Aaron that they will not enter Israel, and refers to the water as "water of Meribah."

children.en: Moses' Prayer after the Sin of the Spies
Moses' Prayer after the Sin of the Calf
Raising Up and Anointing the Tabernacle

description.en: Noah is a biblical figure from the book of [Genesis](https://www.sefaria.org/Genesis?tab=contents), described as the sole righteous person among a wicked generation. When God decided to flood the earth, God warned Noah and instructed him to build an ark. During the flood, Noah, his family, and representatives of every animal survived on the ark.

children.en: Sin and Punishment of the Serpent

description.en: The tree of knowledge is a tree that features in the opening chapters of the [book of Genesis](https://www.sefaria.org/Genesis?tab=contents). God causes the tree to grow in the [Garden of Eden](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/garden-of-eden?tab=sources), and commands [Adam](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/adam?tab=sources) not to eat from it, lest he die. In the following chapter, [Eve](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/eve?tab=sources), following the enticing of a snake, notices the desirable qualities of a tree in the Garden. She eats from the tree's fruits and gives to Adam as well. God then calls out to Adam, and describes consequences that the snake, Eve, and Adam will each face as a result of their actions.

The Binding of Isaac is a story found in Genesis 22, in which God commands Abraham to sacrifice his son, Isaac. Abraham journeys with Isaac to the designated mountain and prepares. As Abraham grabs the knife, an angel of God calls out to him and instructs him not to sacrifice his son. Instead, Abraham sees a ram and sacrifices that instead. The story has inspired generations of analysis and commentary and is traditionally read on Rosh Hashanah, the Jewish new year.

Water turning into blood was the first of ten plagues that God wrought upon the Egyptians when Pharoah refused to let the enslaved Israelites go. It is described in [Exodus 7:14—24](https://www.sefaria.org/Exodus.7.14?ven=The_Koren_Jerusalem_Bible&lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en)

The plague of the firstborn, in which firstborn Egyptian sons died, was the last of ten plagues that God wrought upon the Egyptians when Pharoah refused to let the enslaved Israelites go. It is described throughout [Exodus 11:1—12:36](https://www.sefaria.org/Exodus.11.1?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en).

In the context of the [Exodus story](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/the-exodus-from-egypt?tab=sources), in which God liberates the Israelites from slavery in Egypt, God wreaks a process of ten plagues on [Pharaoh](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/pharaoh?tab=sources) and the Egyptians as Pharaoh repeatedly refuses to let the Israelites go. The Ten Plagues, which appear in Exodus [chapters 7](https://www.sefaria.org/Exodus.7.14?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en) through 12, are: water turned to blood, frogs, lice, wild animals, pestilence of livestock, boils, hail, locusts, darkness, and death of the firstborn. They are recounted and discussed as part of the Passover seder.

The "Ten Commandments" or "Ten Utterances" are the group of the commandments given to the Israelites at Mount Sinai in a constitutive moment of divine revelation to all of the children of Israel. The first set of five commandments establish the rules of God's relationship with humanity, and the second set of five are between people and other people. The Ten Commandments appear twice in the Torah: first, when they are given at Sinai, in [Exodus 20](https://www.sefaria.org/Exodus.20?lang=bi&aliyot=0) and again in [Deuteronomy 5](https://www.sefaria.org/Deuteronomy.5.7?lang=bi&aliyot=0), in Moses' retelling of the earlier narrative.

The Song of the Sea, recorded in [Exodus 15:1–18](https://www.sefaria.org/Exodus.15?lang=bi&aliyot=0), is a song that the Israelites sang upon miraculously crossing the Red Sea. It thanks God for the redemption from slavery in Egypt and celebrates the downfall of the Egyptian oppressors. The song features prominently in Jewish liturgy as part of the daily shacharit (morning) services.

The giving of the Torah is an event described in [Exodus 19–20](https://www.sefaria.org/Exodus.19?lang=bi&aliyot=0) and [Deuteronomy 5](https://www.sefaria.org/Deuteronomy.5.2?lang=bi&aliyot=0), in which God gives the Torah to the Israelites at Mount Sinai. Accompanied by fire, smoke, a cloud, thunder, and lightning, God commands the Ten Commandments. The event is considered a foundational moment in Jewish tradition and is celebrated on the holiday of [Shavuot](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/shavuot?tab=sources).
description.he: מתן תורה (המכונה גם מַעֲמַד הַר סִינָי) מתייחס לאירוע מכונן בהיסטוריה היהודית בו, על פי המסורת, נתן אלוהים את התורה לבני ישראל בהר סִינָי.  מאורע זה מסמל את מערכת היחסים המיוחדת בין אלוהים לעם היהודי, וכן את תפקידה המרכזי של התורה בחיים היהודיים. לכן, מתן תורה הוא מאורע משמעותי ביותר בלוח השנה היהודי, והוא נחגג  כחלק מחג השבועות בתפילות מיוחדות, קריאת התורה ומנהגים מסורתיים הכוללים אכילת מאכלי חלב, לימוד תורה במשך כל הלילה, ועוד.

description.en: The [book of Esther](https://www.sefaria.org/Esther) is one of the five megillot (scrolls), part of the section of the Hebrew Bible called Writings. It tells the story of [Esther](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/esther), a Jew who becomes queen of Persia and together with her cousin, [Mordekhai](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/mordekhai), foils a plot of the evil [Haman](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/haman) to destroy the Jews. To commemorate the transformation from “grief and mourning to festive joy” (9:22), Esther and Mordekhai establish the holiday of [Purim](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/purim). The book of Esther is read publicly in the evening and morning of Purim.
description.he: אחת מחמש המגילות, בה מסופר על השתלשלות האירועים שהובילו לחג הפורים

description.en: The [book of Ruth](https://www.sefaria.org/Ruth.1?lang=bi) is one of the five megillot (scrolls) found in the section of the Hebrew Bible called Writings and is traditionally read on the holiday of Shavuot. It tells the story of [Ruth](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/ruth?tab=sources), a widow of Moabite origin, who insists on staying with her widowed, Israelite mother-in-law, declaring “Wherever you go, I will go... your people shall be my people, and your God my God” (1:16). Ruth’s loyalty leads her to the field of her kinsman, Boaz, whom she ultimately marries. Together they have a child, who later becomes the grandfather of King David.
description.he: מגילת רות היא השנייה בקובץ חמש מגילות שבחטיבת הכתובים שבמקרא, ונקראת בחג השבועות. היא מספרת את סיפורה של רות, אלמנה שמוצאה במואב, הדבקה בחמותה האלמנה היהודייה ומצהירה "באשר תלכי אלך, עמך עמי ואלוקייך אלוקיי" (רות א, טז). נאמנותה של רות מוליכה אותה לשדהו של מיטיבה בועז, והוא נושא אותה לאישה. בנם הנולד להם נעשה לימים סבו של דוד המלך.

description.en: The Second Passover offering.

categoryDescription.he: תורות אזוטריות שעוסקות בשכינה ועל הופעותיה השונות, בבריאה וביחסיו של האל עם האדם.

description.en: *Ab*, or *ayin-bet*, is the numerical value of 72 in Hebrew letters (*ayin*=70; *bet*=2). This numerical value is derived from the letters of the Tetragrammaton, the four-letter name of God referred to as the name of [*Havaya*](/topics/havaya2), when they are spelled in full using the letter *yod*. In other words, each of the letters of the name of [*Havaya*](/topics/havaya2) is written out as a separate word, and the letter *yod* is used in order to fill out the letters: The *yod* is spelled out as *yod-vav-dalet* (יוד), the *heh* is spelled *heh-yod* (הי), the *vav* is spelled *vav-yod-vav* (ויו), and the final *heh* is spelled *heh-yod* (הי).. *Ab* represents the [level](/topics/level) of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) or the light of wisdom. In the world of [*Adam Kadmon*](/topics/adam-kadmon2), *Ab* is the name of the [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) that embodies the [level](/topics/level) of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) (which corresponds to the [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) called [*Abba*](/topics/abba1) in the other four worlds).  The name of *Ab* derived from filling out the letters of the name of [*Havaya*](/topics/havaya2) is not to be confused with the seventy-twoletter ineffable name of God.

There is more than one type of *Ab*.

The name of [*Havaya*](/topics/havaya2), written out in full, with each *yod*:
As is known, the name [*Havaya*](/topics/havaya2) is ten [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot), in which the *yod-heh* are [*Keter*](/topics/keter1), [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), and [*Bina*](/topics/bina3), and the *vav-heh* are *Ze’ir* and [*Nukba*](/topics/nukba). However, it is not yet apparent which level these ten [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) are from, whether on the level of [*nefesh*](/topics/nefesh), [*ruaḥ*](/topics/ruah1), or [*neshama*](/topics/neshama2) etc. This is established by writing out the letters in full – that is, when each letter of the name is spelled out as a word on its own. On the level of [*nefesh*](/topics/nefesh), the letters are written with each *heh*, which leads to a numerical value of 52 (“*Ban*”; the numerical value of yod is 10, the value of vav is 6, the value of dalet is 4, and the value of heh is 5); on the level of [*ruaḥ*](/topics/ruah1) they are written with each *alef*, giving a numerical value of 45 (“*Mah*”); on the level of [*neshama*](/topics/neshama2) they are written with each *yod* (except for the *vav*, which is filled out with an *alef*), leading to a numerical value of 63 (“*Sag*”); and finally, on the level of [*ḥaya*](/topics/haya1) they are all written with each *yod*, including the *vav*, which provides a numerical value of 72 (“*Ab*”) (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 13, Q & A 61).  

The name *Ab Kedem*:
The falling ear nose and mouth of every [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) are restored to it at the time of [maturity](/topics/maturity2), through the illumination of the [fusion](/topics/fusion-through-collision) of [*Ab*](/topics/ab) and [*Sag*](/topics/sag), and which become its [back side](/topics/back-side), that is, new [*Netzaḥ*](/topics/netzah), [*Hod*](/topics/hod1), and [*Yesod*](/topics/yesod1). These are alluded to by the numerical value of *Ab Kedem* (*ayin-bet-kuf-dalet-mem*), which express two back sides of the [head](/topics/head2) and [body](/topics/body3). The plain [*Havaya*](/topics/havaya2) is an expression of the [head](/topics/head2), while its square and [back side](/topics/back-side), that is, *yod*, *yod-heh*, *yod-heh-vav*, *yod-heh-vav-heh*, has a numerical value of 72 (*Ab*). When [*Havaya*](/topics/havaya2) is written out in the manner of [*Ban*](/topics/ban) it is an expression of the [body](/topics/body3), and its [back side](/topics/back-side) is alluded to in the square, that is, *yod-vav-dalet* (for *yod*), *yod-vav-dalet* (for *yod*), *heh-heh* (for *heh*), *yod-vav-dalet* (for *yod*), *heh-heh* (for *heh*), *vav-vav* (for *vav*), *yod-vav-dalet* (for *yod*), *heh-heh* (for *heh*), *vav-vav* (for *vav*), *heh-heh* (for *heh*), which has a numerical value of one hundred and forty-four (*kuf-dalet-mem*, *Kedem*). Together, they have a numerical value of 216. They are the [vessel](/topics/vessel1) that raises the [feminine waters](/topics/feminine-waters2), which comes with the first arrival (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 9, Q & A 81).

“*Ab* (or *ayin-bet*) of *Adam Kadmon*,” or “*Havaya* of *Ab* of *Adam Kadmon*,” is the name of the second [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) of the world of [*Adam Kadmon*](/topics/adam-kadmon2). This [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) is born from the first [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1), called [*gulgalta*](/topics/gulgalta1). It is also called “*partzuf* of *Ḥokhma* of *Adam Kadmon*,” because it is the embodiment of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) in this world.  The name *Ab* stems from the Tetragrammaton, the four-letter name of God, as follows: In each [level](/topics/level) of reality, the four-letter name of God, also referred to as [*Havaya*](/topics/havaya2), is revealed in a unique manner to that [level](/topics/level). This is expressed through the numerical value of the letters of the name, when it is written out in full – that is, when each letter of the name is spelled out as a word on its own. The numerical value of the name of *Havaya* that is unique to the [level](/topics/level) of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) is *ayin-bet*, or 72. This number is derived from writing out the name of *Havaya* by filling out the letters as follows: *yod* (*yod-vav-dalet*), *heh* (*heh-yod*), *vav* (*vav-yod-vav*), *heh* (*heh-yod*) (where the value of the letters is: *yod*=10; *vav*=6; *dalet*=4; *heh*=5).

The [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) formed from [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) is called [*Abba*](/topics/abba1), while the [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) formed from *Binna* is called *Imma*.
When referring only to their upper [*elyon*] sections, they are called [*Abba* and *Imma Ila’in*](/topics/abba-and-imma-ilain).

*Abba* and *Ima Ila'in* (literally "supernal father and mother") is the name for the [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) formed out of the first three [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) of the entire [level](/topics/level) of [*Bina*](/topics/bina3) that was ejected from the [head](/topics/head2) of [*Arikh Anpin*](/topics/arikh-anpin1) as a result of the [second constriction](/topics/second-constriction) and the ascent of [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1). This [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) [enclothes](/topics/enclothe) [*Arikh Anpin*](/topics/arikh-anpin1) from the [mouth](/topics/mouth1) to the chest.
The [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) formed from [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) is called *Abba* (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 2, *Or Penimi*, ch. 5).

*Adam Kadmon* is the first and innermost world, which precedes the four worlds of [*Atzilut*](/topics/atzilut) ([Emanation](/topics/atzilut)), [*Beria*](/topics/beria1) ([Creation](/topics/beria1)), [*Yetzira*](/topics/yetzira1) ([Formation](/topics/yetzira1)), and [*Asiya*](/topics/asiya2) ([Action](/topics/asiya2)). It incorporates all of existence, from its head, that is, the source, which is [*Ein Sof*](/topics/ein-sof1), to its lowest point, which is this physical world. This world is called *Adam Kadmon* because it is depicted in kabbalistic writings in the form of a man, having a head, body and appendages. Although all the worlds are likewise described in the form of a man, this world is the primeval one, before which there is no world, while the other worlds, which are external to it, are “mapped onto it,” lower manifestations of that primeval world: *Atzilut*, from the chest and below to the navel; and *Beria*, *Yetzira*, and *Asiya*, from the navel and below. This world corresponds to the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of [*Keter*](/topics/keter1). Just as [*Keter*](/topics/keter1) itself is often regarded as above the [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot), so too the world of *Adam Kadmon* is sometimes not considered part of the four worlds.

The first world that receives from [*Ein Sof*](/topics/ein-sof1). It is also called “one line,” extending immediately after the [constriction](/topics/constriction) ([*tzimtzum*](/topics/tzimtzum1)) from [*Ein Sof*](/topics/ein-sof1) until near this world. The name “Adam” refers only to the [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) of the straight line in the first world, which is the [light](/topics/light2) of the [*ruaḥ*](/topics/ruah1), meaning the [light](/topics/light2) of giving, not its circular [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot), which contain only the [light](/topics/light2) of [*nefesh*](/topics/nefesh), meaning the [light](/topics/light2) of receiving for themselves, without the ability to give to others. This is the root of man (“Adam”) in this world (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 2, Q & A 1).

This term, literally “the Long Face,” refers to the [partzuf](/topics/partzuf1) in the world of [Atzilut](/topics/atzilut) that it female part corresponds to the lower half of [Keter](/topics/keter1) and the male aspect of the [level](/topics/level) of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1). It is called “long face” in contrast to [Ze’er Anpin](/topics/zeer-anpin1) which means “small face” or “short face.” This [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) is called “long” because it has an abundance of the light of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1). [*Ze’er Anpin*](/topics/zeer-anpin1) contains mainly the [light of giving](/topics/light-of-giving), so it is described as “short” of the light of [Ḥokhma](/topics/hokhma1) compared to *Arikh Anpin*.

The [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) of [*Keter*](/topics/keter1) is called *Arikh Anpin*, or “the long face,” on account of the essence of the [light of *Ḥokhma*](/topics/light-of-hokhma) within it. [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1) is called [*Ze’er Anpin*](/topics/zeer-anpin1), or “the small face,” because it contains only a slight illumination from the [light of *Ḥokhma*](/topics/light-of-hokhma). The names *Arikh Anpin* and [*Ze’er Anpin*](/topics/zeer-anpin1) correspond to one another, for they refer only to the [light of *Ḥokhma*](/topics/light-of-hokhma) in the [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1), since the [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) is called the [light](/topics/light2) of the face, as stated. This must be understood (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 3, Q & A 13).  
The [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) of the [head](/topics/head2) is the mystical concept of an emanator, for a [fusion through collision](/topics/fusion-through-collision) occurs on its [partition](/topics/partition2), meaning a resistance to [enclothing](/topics/enclothe). Accordingly, it is the diametric opposite to [enclothing](/topics/enclothe), which is called an emanated being. How, then, can the one [devolve](/topics/devolvement) from the other? It is for this reason that the [head](/topics/head2), which is called [*Keter*](/topics/keter1), has two levels: The first is [*Atik*](/topics/atik), which is the resistance to [enclothing](/topics/enclothe). It is only the root to the [light](/topics/light2) of *ĥassadim*, where [enclothing](/topics/enclothe) does not occur, because there was no [constriction](/topics/constriction) ([*tzimtzum*](/topics/tzimtzum1)) on the [light](/topics/light2) of *ĥassadim*, and thus it does not suffer from any [opacity](/topics/opacity) ([*ovyut*](/topics/ovyut)) on account of [enclothing](/topics/enclothe) at all. It is considered the root to the second [head](/topics/head2), which is the level of *Arikh Anpin*, the root of the [enclothing](/topics/enclothe), and it serves as the intermediary between emanator and emanated being, since it is the root for the [enclothing](/topics/enclothe) of the [light of *Ḥokhma*](/topics/light-of-hokhma). By contrast, the emanator, which is [*Atik*](/topics/atik), is the opposite of the emanated being, as explained. Accordingly, every [*Keter*](/topics/keter1) is divided into two levels: [*Atik*](/topics/atik), which is only the root to the [light of giving](/topics/light-of-giving), *Arikh Anpin*, which is the root to the [light of *Ḥokhma*](/topics/light-of-hokhma) (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 8, Q & A 130).

The lowest of the four worlds (planes, or [levels](/topics/level) of reality), the world of *Asiya* parallels the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1). Accordingly, it is also correlated with the “fourth [level](/topics/level)” of a given structure of reality, like [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1), which is the fourth [level](/topics/level) of the five main [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) ([*Keter*](/topics/keter1) is the root [level](/topics/level), followed by the next four, hence, the final [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) is considered “fourth,” as is the plane of *Asiya*). It is called *Asiya*, or “Actualization,” because it is where all the wills and forces that descend from the worlds above it are actualized (*na’asim*), or materialized, within it. The lowest [level](/topics/level) of the world of *Asiya* is our material world that we refer to as “this world.” The spiritual entities that exist in the world of *Asiya* are called *ofanim*, which are the spiritual roots of all that exists in the physical reality of this world.
description.he: העולם התחתון מבין ארבעת העולמות, המשתלשלים זה מזה בתהליך הבריאה. הוא נקרא בשם "עשיה" מפני שבו נעשים ויוצאים בפועל כל הרצונות והכוחות שיש בעולמות שמעליו . הדרגה התחתונה של עולם העשיה היא העולם הגשמי שלנו, <<עולם הזה>>. עולם העשיה מקביל בעניינו לספירת ה<<מלכות>> או ל<<בחינה ד'>>. הישויות של עולם העשיה נקראות "אופנים", מעין מלאכים בדרגה נמוכה, שהם השורשים הרוחניים של כל הנמצא בעולם הזה.

description.en: The ten [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) of the level of [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1), which receives from [*Ze’er Anpin*](/topics/zeer-anpin1), are called the world of *Asiya*.

*Atik* is the level of [*Keter*](/topics/keter1) of [*Atzilut*](/topics/atzilut) ([Emanation](/topics/atzilut)) (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 14, Q & A 45).
[*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) of the [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) of the upper [partzuf](/topics/partzuf1) becomes *Atik* of the lower [partzuf](/topics/partzuf1), i.e., from the perspective of its own existence, due to the spark of the Creator it contains, while the spark of the created being within it (see v. 3, Answers, answer 67) becomes *Atik*. Together, they form the [partzuf](/topics/partzuf1) of the lower [*Keter*](/topics/keter1) (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 3, Q & A 79).
The [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) of the [head](/topics/head2) is the mystical concept of an emanator, for a [fusion through collision](/topics/fusion-through-collision) occurs on its [partition](/topics/partition2), meaning a resistance to [enclothing](/topics/enclothe). Accordingly, it is the diametric opposite to [enclothing](/topics/enclothe), which is called an emanated being. How, then, can the one [devolve](/topics/devolvement) from the other? It is for this reason that the [head](/topics/head2), which is called [*Keter*](/topics/keter1), has two levels: The first is *Atik*, which is the resistance to [enclothing](/topics/enclothe). It is only the root to the [light](/topics/light2) of *ĥassadim*, where [enclothing](/topics/enclothe) does not occur, because there was no [constriction](/topics/constriction) ([*tzimtzum*](/topics/tzimtzum1)) upon the [light](/topics/light2) of *ĥassadim*, and thus it does not suffer from any [opacity](/topics/opacity) ([*ovyut*](/topics/ovyut)) on account of [enclothing](/topics/enclothe) at all. It is considered the root to the second [head](/topics/head2), which is the level of [*Arikh Anpin*](/topics/arikh-anpin1), the root of the [enclothing](/topics/enclothe), and it serves as the intermediary between emanator and emanated being, since it is the root for the [enclothing](/topics/enclothe) of the [light of *Ḥokhma*](/topics/light-of-hokhma). By contrast, the emanator, which is *Atik*, is the opposite of the emanated being, as explained. Accordingly, every [*Keter*](/topics/keter1) is divided into two levels: *Atik*, which is only the root to the [light of giving](/topics/light-of-giving), and [*Arikh Anpin*](/topics/arikh-anpin1), which is the root to the [light of *Ḥokhma*](/topics/light-of-hokhma) (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 8, Q & A 130).

Often translated as bounty, flow, or abundance, *shefa* comes from the Hebrew word *hashpa’a*, which in this context means to give. Rays of sunlight, for example, can be described as the sun’s *shefa*. The rays constitute a “flow” of light from the sun that provides light and sustenance to the earth in bountiful abundance. In kabbalistic thought, *shefa* refers to different forms of light that flow from God's essence or from the [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) and the like. Additionally, *shefa* can be used to refer both to God’s giving to creation, as well as the giving of created beings to each other.
The part of a [vessel](/topics/vessel1) that is not designed to receive or give is called the back side. See “the way of the back side” (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 4, Q & A 9).

*Ban*, or *bet-nun*, is the numerical value of 52 in Hebrew letters (*nun*=50; *bet*=2). This numerical value is derived from the letters of the Tetragrammaton, the four-letter name of God referred to as the name of [Havaya](/topics/havaya2), when they are spelled out in full using the letter *heh*. In other words, each of its letters of the name of [Havaya](/topics/havaya2) is written out as a separate word, and the letter *heh* is used in order to fill out the letters, as follows: The *yod* is spelled out as *yod-vav-dalet* (יוד), the *heh* is spelled *heh-heh* (הה), the *vav* is spelled *vav-vav* (וו), and the final *heh* is spelled *heh-heh* (הה). *Ban* represents the [level](/topics/level) of [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) or the light of [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1).

The first [fusion](/topics/fusion-through-collision) for the[*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) of the *nekudim* (points) was in the “apertures of the eyes” of the [head](/topics/head2) of the [*Sag*](/topics/sag), and yet the ear nose and mouth of the [head](/topics/head2) did not bring the [*Sag*](/topics/sag) to the outside, since there is no such thing as loss in the spiritual plane. The division of the level had no effect on the [head](/topics/head2) of the [*Sag*](/topics/sag), other than with respect to an additional [face](/topics/partzuf1), which is the [face](/topics/partzuf1) of the hairs. For the hairs of the [head](/topics/head2) emerged from apertures of the eyes and above, and from that point and below the hairs of the beard emerged as ear nose and mouth (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 6, Q & A 28).

The world of *Beria* is the second of the four worlds (after the supernal world of *Adam Kadmon*) that emanate and descend from another in the process of creation. According to one explanation, its name is derived from the Hebrew word *bar*, a term that connotes that which is external, implying that the world of *Beria* is a garment for the world of [*Atzilut*](/topics/atzilut). The world of *Beria* parallels the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of [*Bina*](/topics/bina3), or the second [level](/topics/level) of creation, and it is the beginning point of the [enclothing](/topics/enclothe) of [*Atzilut*](/topics/atzilut) into a reality that created beings can receive. The world of *Beria* is also called the world of the throne, signifying the Divine lowering itself onto a throne, so to speak, to interact with its creations and the beginning of the revelation of the Divine to lower [levels](/topics/level) of existence. It is also known as the world of souls, since the created entities called souls begin to have significance as receivers of the supernal light. The angelic entities that exist in this world are called *serafim*.

The bringing forth of something into existence ex nihilo, [*yesh* *me*’*ayin*](/topics/yesh-meayin), is known as *Beria* (Creation). Since the [opacity](/topics/opacity) ([*ovyut*](/topics/ovyut)) in the vessels cannot be revealed in the world of [*Atzilut*](/topics/atzilut) ([Emanation](/topics/atzilut)), but only from the ground of the world of [*Atzilut*](/topics/atzilut) ([Emanation](/topics/atzilut)) and below, it is therefore called *Beria* from that point and below, after the [opacity](/topics/opacity) ([*ovyut*](/topics/ovyut)) that has been revealed. For the [opacity](/topics/opacity) ([*ovyut*](/topics/ovyut)), which is comprised of the [will to receive](/topics/will-to-receive) in the created being, is a form of [*yesh* *me*’*ayin*](/topics/yesh-meayin), creation from nothing. Everything that exists is drawn from God as *yesh miyesh*, literally “something from something,” because there is nothing He does not have, apart from a “will of receiving,” which of necessity He does not possess, since there is no one from whom He could receive, God forbid. This must be understood.

*Bina* is the third of the ten [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot), following the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1). It is the second [level](/topics/level) of the supernal light, or direct light, that emanates from the essence of the Creator. This second [level](/topics/level) or phase represents the desire of the created being to give and bestow and is therefore called the light of giving, as a continuation of the light of the Creator, the light of wisdom. It is called *Bina* or Understanding, because from it flows forth the power of understanding, of apprehending one thing for another. *Bina* is also a reference to different lower [levels](/topics/level) or *sefirot* in the structure of reality that are derivatives of the second [level](/topics/level) of the direct light.  *Bina* is considered a “female” (or receiving) *sefira*, because it receives the light of wisdom. Additionally, at the root of *Bina* lies the yearning of the created beings that represents the will to receive that is embedded in existence. From a different perspective, *Bina* is found in of the [head](/topics/head2) of the [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) constructs, that is in the mind, so to speak, which includes the first three [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) of [*Keter*](/topics/keter1), [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), and *Bina*.  Each of the five primary [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) is parallel to one of the five worlds that form existence. The world that is parallel to the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of *Bina* is the world of [*Beria*](/topics/beria1). Each of the five primary *sefirot* is also parallel to one of the five [*partzufim*](/topics/partzuf). The [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) that is parallel to *Bina* is called *Imma*, or “Mother.” Like a mother, *Bina* contains the roots of the *sefirot* that emanate from it, [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1) with its [*six extremities*](/topics/six-extremities) and [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1). Additionally, the second [constriction](/topics/constriction) ([*tzimtzum*](/topics/tzimtzum1)) that forms the backdrop for the [*world of tikkun](/topics/world-of-tikkun) ([rectification](/topics/world-of-tikkun))*, takes place within the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of *Bina*.

The [light](/topics/light2) initially spreads and emerges from the Creator as [light of *Ḥokhma*](/topics/light-of-hokhma), which is the entirety of its life force belonging to that emanated being. It incorporates the first [level](/topics/level) of the [will to receive](/topics/will-to-receive) and is called the first expansion, or the first [level](/topics/level). Subsequently, a will of giving prevails in that [light](/topics/light2). The prevailing of this will draws out [light](/topics/light2) of *ĥassadim* from the Creator, which is called the first prevailment, or the second [level](/topics/level) (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 1, Q & A 69).

The term *guf*, body, essentially has three meanings in kabbalistic literature. The first is the vessel for the supernal light. Just as the physical body is a vessel for the soul, so too vessels of all kinds and on all [levels](/topics/level) of reality are called bodies (while the lights within them are called *neshamot*, souls). Second, “body” can refer to the central and important aspect that defines each [level](/topics/level). The third meaning of “body” is in the context of the structure of a [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1): the [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) of [*Ḥesed*](/topics/hesed), [*Gevura*](/topics/gevura), and [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), or sometimes [*Ḥesed*](/topics/hesed), [*Gevura*](/topics/gevura), [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), [*Netzaḥ*](/topics/netzah), [*Hod*](/topics/hod1), and [*Yesod*](/topics/yesod1), contained in the [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) are called the body of the [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1), in contrast to the first three [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) contained in the [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) – [*Keter*](/topics/keter1), [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), and [*Bina*](/topics/bina3)  – which are considered the [head](/topics/head2) of the [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1).

The [enclothing](/topics/enclothe) of the lights in the vessels must initially be in “potential” form, and only subsequently “actualized.” The [enclothing](/topics/enclothe) of the ten [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) in “potential” form is called [head](/topics/head2), while the [enclothing](/topics/enclothe) of the ten [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) in “actualized” form is called body (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 4, Q & A 13).

The term “brains” (*moḥin*) generally refers to different [levels](/topics/level) of the light and vessels that are acquired by a particular [level](/topics/level) or [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1). Through the different processes of ascent and descent of different [*partzufim*](/topics/partzuf) and [levels](/topics/level), different lights are acquired by those [levels](/topics/level) or [*partzufim*](/topics/partzuf). The acquisition of these new “brains” can be thought of as similar to the human concept of mental development, in which a person’s mind expands and matures. Accordingly, the acquisition of brains is often called the [maturity](/topics/maturity2) of the [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) . The reason this expansion is called a “brain” is because these new lights either form a new [head](/topics/head2) or are received in an existing [head](/topics/head2) of a [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1).
The lights of the [head](/topics/head2) are called brains (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 8, Q & A 32).
The chest is the endpoint of the [second constriction](/topics/second-constriction) (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 16, Q & A 94).
That which overcomes its will, i.e., restrains itself and does not receive even though he greatly yearns to receive, is described as “constricting” itself (Talmud Eser Sefirot, v. 1, Q & A 46).

There are a number of ways to count and categorize the [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot). The most well-known count is that of ten, including [*Keter*](/topics/keter1), [*Hokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), [*Bina*](/topics/bina3), [*Hesed*](/topics/hesed), [*Gevura*](/topics/gevura), [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), [*Netzah*](/topics/netzah), [*Hod*](/topics/hod1), [*Yesod*](/topics/yesod1) and [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1). This count can be thought of as the “core” [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot), the root ingredients of everything in existence. However, an alternative count of ten [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) removes [*Keter*](/topics/keter1) and adds the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of *Da’at* after [*Bina*](/topics/bina3). *Da’at* is not a true substitute for [*Keter*](/topics/keter1), as it is not one of the core [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot). Instead, it is a pseudo-[*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) formed during a process called the “rectification of lines.” During this process, and as a result of the [second constriction](/topics/second-constriction), two columns of light are formed, one associated with the right (the [light of giving](/topics/light-of-giving)), and one associated with the left (the light of [*Hokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), able to be received only by vessels formed of the will to receive). These two columns are described as in conflict, unable to “work together” and therefore unable to serve their function of merging and transmitting supernal light to lower [levels](/topics/level). The rectification of this conflicted state comes through a middle line or column of light that ascends from below and mediates between the two sides. The root of this middle column is [*Ze’er Anpin*](/topics/zeer-anpin1), the [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) below, and its ascended form is *Da’at*, the pseudo-[*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) meant to unite the opposing sides.

The Hebrew word for devolvement, *hishtalshelut*, has the same root as the Hebrew word *leshalshel*, which means to lower, and *shalshelet*, chain. The devolvement, or *hishtalshelut*, represents the [levels](/topics/level) or stages of the creation of the world, beginning from the source, [*Ein Sof*](/topics/ein-sof1) Himself, and culminating with the physical world. This series of stages is compared to a linked metal chain, in which each link is connected to its adjoining links above and beneath it. Similarly, each [*level*](/topics/level) of reality is linked with the [*level*](/topics/level) above it, as well as the [*level*](/topics/level) below it, like a series of links in a chain.

The diaphragm (*parsa*) is a term describing the separation between the world [*Atzilut*](/topics/atzilut) and the worlds below. This separation is a result of the [second constriction](/topics/second-constriction), in which [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1), with its attendant first [constriction](/topics/constriction), ascended to the [level](/topics/level) of [*Bina*](/topics/bina3). In Kabbalah language, the structures of the [*partzufim*](/topics/partzuf) and the [levels](/topics/level) are described using terms derived from the human body. The diaphragm in the body lies at the point of the chest, similar to the location of the [level](/topics/level) of [*Bina*](/topics/bina3) within the [body](/topics/body3) of a [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1).

Direct light (*or yashar*) refers to the flow of the light from above to below. This light flows from the source, the [*Ein Sof*](/topics/ein-sof1), in a set of ten [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) called the “ten [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) of the direct light. This is in contrast to the [returning light](/topics/returning-light1), which flows from below to above as a result of the [partition](/topics/partition2) upon [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1)

The upper [light](/topics/light2) that is drawn from [*Ein Sof*](/topics/ein-sof1) and given in the [*partzufim*](/topics/partzuf), after the [constriction](/topics/constriction) ([*tzimtzum*](/topics/tzimtzum1)) and onwards. It is called by this name to indicate that it is not given in the > of the circular [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot). The same applies to all levels that contain nothing of the [opacity](/topics/opacity) ([*ovyut*](/topics/ovyut)) of the fourth level, except for the [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) of the straight line alone. This is in accordance with the general rule that one who bestows does so only in something that is more opaque, which is the [*opacity*](/topics/opacity) ([ovyut](/topics/ovyut)) of the fourth level (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 2, Q & A 3).

A name for the three levels and the vessels that emerge from each [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) of the [head](/topics/head2).
The “ears”: [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) of the second level. 
The “nose”: [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) of the third level. 
The “mouth”: [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) of the fourth level. 
After the second [constriction](/topics/constriction) ([*tzimtzum*](/topics/tzimtzum1)), in which the [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) once again joined [*Bina*](/topics/bina3), each ear nose and mouth fell to the level below them.

There are various ways in which the name *Eheyeh*, which alludes to *Imma*, can be written out in full – that is, when each letter of the name is spelled out as a word on its own. The following must be understood:
The [letters](/topics/letters1) of the names allude to the vessels and their level of [opacity](/topics/opacity) ([*ovyut*](/topics/ovyut)), when the supernal light fuses and is [enclothed](/topics/enclothe) in them. The plain [letters](/topics/letters1) of the name allude to the [opacity](/topics/opacity) ([*ovyut*](/topics/ovyut)) of [*Keter*](/topics/keter1), where the [opacity](/topics/opacity) ([*ovyut*](/topics/ovyut)) is not yet recognizable but is merely a root. Accordingly, the > that is [enclothed](/topics/enclothe) there is only the [light](/topics/light2) of [*nefesh*](/topics/nefesh), for the [light](/topics/light2) of [*nefesh*](/topics/nefesh) is [enclothed](/topics/enclothe) in the [vessel](/topics/vessel1) of [*Keter*](/topics/keter1), as is known. If, however, the [letters](/topics/letters1) are written out in full, this indicates that the [opacity](/topics/opacity) ([*ovyut*](/topics/ovyut)) is already recognizable, that the supernal light is fusing above it, producing the ten [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) which refer to that measure of [opacity](/topics/opacity) ([*ovyut*](/topics/ovyut)) (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 12, Q & A 1). 
The different meanings of these “writings in full” vary: “The level of the upper *Imma* divides into a [head](/topics/head2), [body](/topics/body3), and legs; [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), [*Bina*](/topics/bina3), and *Daat*; [*Ḥesed*](/topics/hesed), [*Gevura*](/topics/gevura); and [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), [*Netzaḥ*](/topics/netzah), [*Hod*](/topics/hod1), and [*Yesod*](/topics/yesod1). The name *Eheyeh*, when the [letters](/topics/letters1) *yod* are written out in full (in its *yod* and *heh*), which are [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), [*Bina*](/topics/bina3), and *Daat*, receives from the corresponding level in the [*Sag*](/topics/sag) of [*Adam Kadmon*](/topics/adam-kadmon2) that is from the navel and below, where the [second constriction](/topics/second-constriction) has not yet taken root, which is the expression of the *alef*. The name *Eheyeh* with each *alef* is in its [*Ḥesed*](/topics/hesed), [*Gevura*](/topics/gevura), and [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), which receives from the corresponding level, below the navel of [*Adam Kadmon*](/topics/adam-kadmon2), where the [second constriction](/topics/second-constriction) has already taken root. That is why it is written out in full with each *alef*, as stated on p. 463, Answer 1. The *Eheyeh* with each *heh* is in its [*Netzaḥ*](/topics/netzah), [*Hod*](/topics/hod1), and [*Yesod*](/topics/yesod1), which are the [back side](/topics/back-side), written out in full with each *heh*” (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 2, Q & A 16).

In kabbalistic literature, *Ein Sof*, or the Infinite One, has two meanings. One is the initial stage of creation, what is referred to as the Creator’s intent for creation, before the first [constriction](/topics/constriction) ([*tzimtzum*](/topics/tzimtzum1)), when the light and vessel are infinite. That is, there is an infinite will to receive that draws into it infinite light. The other meaning of *Ein Sof* is a “relative” *Ein Sof*, which is the [*Keter*](/topics/keter1) of each [level](/topics/level) of reality, because in relation to the [levels](/topics/level) beneath it, [*Keter*](/topics/keter1) is regarded as absolute light, without vessel or limitation. Thus, for example, the world of [*Adam Kadmon*](/topics/adam-kadmon2) is defined as *Ein Sof* in relation to the worlds of [*Atzilut*](/topics/atzilut), [*Beria*](/topics/beria1), [*Yetzira*](/topics/yetzira1), and [*Asiya*](/topics/asiya2), because the world of [*Adam Kadmon*](/topics/adam-kadmon2) is the [*Keter*](/topics/keter1) [level](/topics/level) of the lower four worlds. Similarly, the [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) called Atik (literally, “Ancient”), the highest [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) of an individual world, is the [*Keter*](/topics/keter1) of its respective world, and is defined as *Ein Sof* in relation to that world. The same applies to the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of [*Keter*](/topics/keter1) in each [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1): It is defined as *Ein Sof* relative to that [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1). The focus of most of the *Zohar* is on this relative *Ein Sof*.

Any [level](/topics/level) of reality that incorporates another [level](/topics/level) within it is called the external clothing of the inner [level](/topics/level), and the inner [level](/topics/level) is enclothed within that outer [level](/topics/level). For example, a vessel that contains the light is also the clothing of the light and the light is enclothed within it. Likewise, the body is described as clothing for the soul.

When discussing intangible spiritual [levels](/topics/level) or entities, the concepts of space and physical proximity do not apply. Spiritual entities and [levels](/topics/level) have different conceptual forms, or “*tzura*,” referring to the parameters or characteristics of a [level](/topics/level) or aspect. When a spiritual entity adapts its nature so that it resembles another entity, the two entities are said to have achieved an equating of form. This equating of form creates a state called *devekut*, bonding, attachment, or merging one with the other. While in the physical world, two entities are attached or joined through physical proximity, in the nonspatial spiritual realm, attachment is achieved through the equating of form.
The [vessel](/topics/vessel1) of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) of the [head](/topics/head2) (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 3, Q & A 76).

When the female receives the supernal light from the > of the male into her internal vessels, this is called a face-to-face [fusion](/topics/fusion-through-collision) (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 7, Q & A 73).

The ascent of feminine waters (*mayan nukvin*) is a term referring to the "yearning" from below for the light from the [levels](/topics/level) above. In Kabbalah and Torah thought, the concept of female denotes the dynamic of receiving, while male denotes giving. The “giving” from above to below is described as "masculine waters," and denotes the dynamic of giving from the divine source to the lower beings. The lower beings are the “receivers'' of this divine light, and accordingly, their yearning for that light is described as a “flow” of “feminine waters” from below to above. When feminine waters arise, they cause [fusion through collision](/topics/fusion-through-collision) that draws new light down, considered to be “masculine waters.”

It is known that as a result of the expansion of the [points](/topics/points) of [*Sag*](/topics/sag) to [*Mah*](/topics/mah1) and [*Ban*](/topics/ban) of the inner [*Adam Kadmon*](/topics/adam-kadmon2), [traces](/topics/traces) of two levels are joined in the [partition](/topics/partition2). These are the first *heh* in [*Sag*](/topics/sag), and the bottom *heh* in the inner [*Adam Kadmon*](/topics/adam-kadmon2). Thus, the [partition](/topics/partition2) is incorporated from two females, [*Bina*](/topics/bina3) and [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1). For this reason the [partition](/topics/partition2) was given the name feminine waters, since from this point onwards it incorporates these two females in every [fusion](/topics/fusion-through-collision) it performs with the supernal light (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 6, Q & A 15). 
The meaning of feminine waters is that it causes a [fusion](/topics/fusion-through-collision). It is always an expression of [*Netzaḥ*](/topics/netzah), [*Hod*](/topics/hod1), and [*Yesod*](/topics/yesod1), or *Ze’ir* and [*Nukba*](/topics/nukba). For the female is instituted in the [light](/topics/light2) of the [back side](/topics/back-side) of *Imma*, which is attached only to the [light of giving](/topics/light-of-giving) and which rebuffs [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1). Accordingly, she does not turn her face towards the male to receive the illumination of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), unless she is forced by some factor to do so. This factor is an expression of *Ze’ir* and [*Nukba*](/topics/nukba), to which the [*Bina*](/topics/bina3) has a connection, to illuminate it with the illumination of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), due to the relationship between [*Bina*](/topics/bina3) and the *Ze’ir* and [*Nukba*](/topics/nukba) of the [direct light](/topics/direct-light1). Consequently, when the *Ze’ir* and [*Nukba*](/topics/nukba) ascends to her for feminine waters, her [back side](/topics/back-side) immediately stops, and she turns her face to the [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), to receive from it the illumination of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1). She thus engages in a face-to-face [fusion](/topics/fusion-through-collision) with it (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 7, Q & A 35).

The [light](/topics/light2) initially spreads and emerges from the Creator as [light of *Ḥokhma*](/topics/light-of-hokhma), which is the entirety of its life force belonging to that emanated being. It incorporates the first [level](/topics/level) of the [will to receive](/topics/will-to-receive) and is called the first expansion, or the first [level](/topics/level). Subsequently, a will of giving prevails in that [light](/topics/light2). The prevailing of this will draws out [light](/topics/light2) of *ĥassadim* from the Creator, and this is called the first prevailment, or the second [level](/topics/level). Next, that [light](/topics/light2) of *ĥassadim* expands with a great expansion, that is, with the illumination of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), which is called the second expansion, or the third [level](/topics/level). Then the [will to receive](/topics/will-to-receive), which is incorporated in the [light](/topics/light2) from the first expansion, as stated, once again prevails in that [light](/topics/light2), thereby completing the [will to receive](/topics/will-to-receive) in its mature, full form. This is called the second prevailment, or the fourth [level](/topics/level) (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 1, Q & A 69).

The first three are the lights that came before the vessels, which are [enclothed](/topics/enclothe) in the [returning light](/topics/returning-light1) that ascends to them from the [partition](/topics/partition2) which is from them and above. That is, the first three [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) – [*Keter*](/topics/keter1), [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), and [*Bina*](/topics/bina3) – which are also known as the [head](/topics/head2) of the [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 2, Q & A 13).
Those first three and the [head](/topics/head2) are the ten [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) of [direct light](/topics/direct-light1), which are [enclothed](/topics/enclothe) in the [returning light](/topics/returning-light1) that ascends from the [partition](/topics/partition2) and above, meaning the beginning and root. For they are not yet considered complete vessels that are suited to the full [enclothing](/topics/enclothe) of the [light](/topics/light2), but only as roots (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 3, Q & A 96).

The ten [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) have five levels, [*Keter*](/topics/keter1), [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), [*Bina*](/topics/bina3), *Ze’ir*, and [*Nukba*](/topics/nukba), when the [first three](/topics/first-three1) are essences. However, when their entire essence is nothing other than [light](/topics/light2) of [*ḥassadim*](/topics/hassadim), the five levels are [*Ḥesed*](/topics/hesed), [*Gevura*](/topics/gevura), [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), [*Netzaḥ*](/topics/netzah) and [*Hod*](/topics/hod1), that is, five [*ḥassadim*](/topics/hassadim). If they are expressions of [restraints](/topics/restraints), meaning the illumination of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) without [*ḥassadim*](/topics/hassadim), the five levels, [*Ḥesed*](/topics/hesed), [*Gevura*](/topics/gevura), [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), [*Netzaḥ*](/topics/netzah) and [*Hod*](/topics/hod1), are called five [restraints](/topics/restraints). Thus, there are three expressions of the five levels: If their essence is [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) they are called [*Keter*](/topics/keter1), [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), [*Bina*](/topics/bina3), *Ze’ir*, and [*Nukba*](/topics/nukba); if their essence is [*ḥassadim*](/topics/hassadim) and they have the illumination of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) they are called five [*ḥassadim*](/topics/hassadim), [*Ḥesed*](/topics/hesed), [*Gevura*](/topics/gevura), [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), [*Netzaḥ*](/topics/netzah) and [*Hod*](/topics/hod1); and if they lack [*ḥassadim*](/topics/hassadim) and are left with the illumination of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) alone they are called five [restraints](/topics/restraints), [*Ḥesed*](/topics/hesed), [*Gevura*](/topics/gevura), [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), [*Netzaḥ*](/topics/netzah) and [*Hod*](/topics/hod1) (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 7, Q & A 37).

The [light](/topics/light2) initially spreads and emerges from the Creator as [light of *Ḥokhma*](/topics/light-of-hokhma), which is the entirety of its life force belonging to that emanated being. It incorporates the first [level](/topics/level) of the [will to receive](/topics/will-to-receive) and is called the first expansion, or the first [level](/topics/level). Subsequently, a will of giving prevails in that [light](/topics/light2). The prevailing of this will draws out [light](/topics/light2) of *ĥassadim* from the Creator, and this is called the first prevailment, or the second [level](/topics/level). Next, that [light](/topics/light2) of *ĥassadim* expands with a great expansion, that is, with the illumination of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), which is called the second expansion, or the third [level](/topics/level). Then the [will to receive](/topics/will-to-receive), which is incorporated in the [light](/topics/light2) from the first expansion, as stated, once again prevails in that [light](/topics/light2), thereby completing the [will to receive](/topics/will-to-receive) in its mature, full form. This is called the second prevailment, or the fourth [level](/topics/level) (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 1, Q & A 69).

The [level](/topics/level) of [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) that exists in every [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) contains two aspects. One is the fusing *Malkhut*. When there is a [fusion through collision](/topics/fusion-through-collision) in the [partition](/topics/partition2) that is positioned above the [level](/topics/level) of [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1), where the supernal light is rebuffed by the [partition](/topics/partition2) because it prevents the supernal light from entering this [level](/topics/level), the light that rises from it [enclothes](/topics/enclothe) the supernal light, thereby producing the next [level](/topics/level). The second aspect of [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) is the [terminating *Malkhut*](/topics/terminating-malkhut), where the [partition](/topics/partition2) above it stops the supernal light from spreading into it, serving as terminal for the [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) and determining where it will end.

Fusion through collision refers to the clash between the supernal light, which shines continuously, and a [partition](/topics/partition2), which is the force of resistance of a created being, or [*vessel*](/topics/vessel1), to receiving the supernal light. When the supernal light is rebuffed by the created entity, the fusion through collision produces the [returning light](/topics/returning-light1), which initiates the process through which a new vessel or entity is created. In this context, “fusion” denotes the merging of two entities, which leads to the formation of a new entity, while “collision” means opposition and rejection. These concepts express the two opposing forces that act upon the [partition](/topics/partition2): [opacity](/topics/opacity) ([*ovyut*](/topics/ovyut)), which constitutes the will to receive the supernal light, and [hardness](/topics/kashyut) ([*kashyut*](/topics/kashyut)), which is the force of resistance to the light and its repulsion. These two opposing forces act in parallel and cause the vessel to draw the supernal light in on one hand and rebuff it on the other, thus forming the [returning light](/topics/returning-light1). It is this coupling interaction that gives birth to the new [level](/topics/level) and [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1).

The expansion of the [light](/topics/light2) of [*Ein Sof*](/topics/ein-sof1) for the [fusion through collision](/topics/fusion-through-collision) in the [partition](/topics/partition2) in the [vessel](/topics/vessel1) of the [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) in order to raise [returning light](/topics/returning-light1) is called gaze. This is because the [light](/topics/light2) that expands from [*Ein Sof*](/topics/ein-sof1) is always considered [light of *Ḥokhma*](/topics/light-of-hokhma), which is termed [light](/topics/light2) of the [eyes](/topics/eyes4), or “sight,” or gaze (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 6, section 36).
The giving of the [brains](/topics/brains2) from a higher level to a lower one is called the “upper gaze,” since the gaze is drawn from the [eyes](/topics/eyes4), that is, from [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) of the [head](/topics/head2), which is called [eyes](/topics/eyes4), as is known (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 15, Q & A 36).
The totality of giving that comes from [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) is called gaze.

Fusions at the stage of [immaturity](/topics/immaturity1) are called gestation (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 8, Q & A 42). Likewise, the stage of [*nefesh*](/topics/nefesh) is also called gestation (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 15, Q & A 21).
Here is an example in [*Ze*’*er* *Anpin*](/topics/zeer-anpin1):
The initial formation of [*Ze*’*er* *Anpin*](/topics/zeer-anpin1) is by means of its incorporation in the fusions of [*Abba* and *Imma*](/topics/abba-and-imma), in the mystical meaning of the ascent of the [feminine waters](/topics/feminine-waters2) to them. This incorporation is called the first gestation of [*Ze*’*er* *Anpin*](/topics/zeer-anpin1). Later, after its [six extremities](/topics/six-extremities) have already been completed in eveything, it ascends a second time to [*Abba* and *Imma*](/topics/abba-and-imma) for [feminine waters](/topics/feminine-waters2), and is incorporated in their [fusion](/topics/fusion-through-collision) of [maturity](/topics/maturity2). This is called the second gestation, which is to attain the [brains](/topics/brains2) of [maturity](/topics/maturity2) (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 10, Q & A 70).

The [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of *Gevura* is the fifth of the ten [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot). When the [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) are divided into the five primary [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) – [*Keter*](/topics/keter1), [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), [*Bina*](/topics/bina3), [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), and [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) – *Gevura* is encompassed in the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1) as the [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) [level](/topics/level) of [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1) (see [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1))  The [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of *Gevura* is called by this name since it characterizes restraint and constriction. It represents the left column in a process called the rectification of lines, and it is this left column on which the [constriction](/topics/constriction) ([*tzimtzum*](/topics/tzimtzum1)) acts. This placement characterizes the power of restraint that is used to repel the supernal light. In the structure of [*partzufim*](/topics/partzuf), which is analogous to the human body, *Gevura* is generally presented as the left hand of the *partzuf*.

An Aramaic word meaning “skull,” *gulgalta* represents the [level](/topics/level) of [*Keter*](/topics/keter1) in all of the various [*partzufim*](/topics/partzuf), which are each composed of a [head](/topics/head2), [body](/topics/body3), and legs, similar to the form of the human body. Each [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) has the same corresponding [levels](/topics/level), and the *gulgalta* is the highest [level](/topics/level) of a particular [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1).

The [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) of the [*Keter*](/topics/keter1). The [vessel](/topics/vessel1) where the [light](/topics/light2) of [*yeḥida*](/topics/yehida1) is [enclothed](/topics/enclothe) is also called [*gulgalta*](/topics/gulgalta1) (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 3, Q & A 22), as well as the [vessel](/topics/vessel1) of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) of the [head](/topics/head2) (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 3, Q & A 76).
After the second [constriction](/topics/constriction) ([*tzimtzum*](/topics/tzimtzum1)) they are considered the main part of the [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1).

The [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) of the [*Keter*](/topics/keter1). The [vessel](/topics/vessel1) where the [light](/topics/light2) of [*yeḥida*](/topics/yehida1) is [enclothed](/topics/enclothe) is also called *gulgalta* (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 3, Q & A 22).

The [light of giving](/topics/light-of-giving) (“*ĥassadim*”) is the [light](/topics/light2) that [enclothes](/topics/enclothe) upon [light of *Ḥokhma*](/topics/light-of-hokhma) and is drawn to the emanated being at the first prevailment (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 1, Q & A 6).

The name of *Havaya* refers to the Tetragrammaton, the four-letter name of God comprised of the letters *yod-heh-vav-heh*. It is pronounced Havaya rather than its true pronunciation on account of its sanctity and in order to avoid unwittingly violating the Torah prohibition against uttering the name of God. It is often written in this form in order to avoid the prohibition against erasing the name of God.  This name of God represents the main [levels](/topics/level) of existence. Its four letters correspond to four of the five primary [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot): the *yod­* parallels [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1); the first *heh*, [*Bina*](/topics/bina3); the *vav*, [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1); and the final *heh*, [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1)), while the upper point of the *yod* corresponds to the fifth, [*Keter*](/topics/keter1), the root of all the [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot). The letters of the name also parallel the four worlds, [*Atzilut](/topics/atzilut) ([Emanation](/topics/atzilut))*, [*Beria](/topics/beria1) ([Creation](/topics/beria1))*, [*Yetzira](/topics/yetzira1) ([Formation](/topics/yetzira1))*, and [*Asiya](/topics/asiya2) ([Action](/topics/asiya2))*, while the upper point of the *yod* parallels the world of [*Adam Kadmon*](/topics/adam-kadmon2).  Just as each of the letters of the name corresponds to a different [level](/topics/level) of reality, so too the various ways of writing the name express different [levels](/topics/level) in the upper worlds. Thus, for example, the name [*Ab*](/topics/ab) is the one that is revealed in the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) in every [level](/topics/level) of reality. At the same time, every [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) has a specific name (“*Havaya*”) that is revealed through it, e. g., the name that is revealed in the second [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) of [*Adam Kadmon*](/topics/adam-kadmon2) is “*Havaya* of *Ab* of *Adam Kadmon*,” and it refers to that [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1).

The name of *Havaya* refers to the Tetragrammaton, the four-letter name of God comprised of the letters *yod-heh-vav-heh*.
