Then the [will to receive](/topics/will-to-receive), which is incorporated in the [light](/topics/light2) from the first expansion, as stated, once again prevails in that [light](/topics/light2), thereby completing the [will to receive](/topics/will-to-receive) in its mature, full form. This is called the second prevailment, or the fourth [level](/topics/level) (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 1, Q & A 69).

The [*Bina*](/topics/bina3) that emerged outside of the [head](/topics/head2) of [*Arikh Anpin*](/topics/arikh-anpin1) is called throat (*garon*), as in the phrase “a stranger [*ger*] in a strange land” (see Exodus 18:3), for it emerged to a place that is unsuitable for it. Likewise, every [*Bina*](/topics/bina3) that emerges outside of the [head](/topics/head2) is called a throat (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 8, Q & A 12).

The [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of *Tiferet* is the sixth of the ten [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot). When the [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) are divided into the five primary [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) – [*Keter*](/topics/keter1), [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), [*Bina*](/topics/bina3), *Tiferet*, and [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) –*Tiferet* is parallel to the third [level](/topics/level) of the direct light of giving emanating from the Creator. This [level](/topics/level) of light is primarily drawn from the desire of the created beings to bond with the Creator, a will to give, but it also contains a certain amount of the will to receive the light of the Creator, which draws in illuminations from the light of wisdom.  *Tiferet* means “Beauty” (the concept of harmony), and it is called by this name because it is able to integrate both kinds of light within it, the light of wisdom, and the light of giving. This integration, which can be thought of as being formed of two columns of light, as well as an intermediating column which connects them, is the harmonious beauty of this *sefira*. It is this integrative capacity and its unique combination of lights that gives *Tiferet* its unique characterization in which the five *sefirot* that comprise it are given different names (recall that each *sefira* is formed of all five *sefirot*): The [*Keter*](/topics/keter1) in *Tiferet* is called [*Ḥesed*](/topics/hesed). The [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) in *Tiferet* is called [*Gevura*](/topics/gevura). The [*Bina*](/topics/bina3) in *Tiferet* is called *Tiferet*. The *Tiferet* within *Tiferet* is called *Netzaḥ*. The [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) within *Tiferet* is called [*Hod*](/topics/hod1). In addition to these five, there is a sixth [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) in *Tiferet* called [*Yesod*](/topics/yesod1), which includes the preceding five within it. It is this grouping of the [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) that gives rise to the familiar count of ten [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot).  In the structure of [*partzufim*](/topics/partzuf), *Tiferet* is considered the [body](/topics/body3) of the [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1). Two hands ([*Ḥesed*](/topics/hesed) and [*Gevura*](/topics/gevura)) emerge from the [body](/topics/body3), as well as two legs ([*Netzaḥ*](/topics/netzah) and [*Hod*](/topics/hod1)) and the limb of procreation and life ([*Yesod*](/topics/yesod1)), thus forming the image of the human body. The [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) that correlates to *Tiferet* is [*Ze’er Anpin*](/topics/zeer-anpin1), which encompasses the [*six extremities*](/topics/six-extremities). Each of the five primary [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) is also parallel to one of the five worlds that form existence. The world that correlates to the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of *Tiferet* is the world of [*Yetzira*](/topics/yetzira1).
description.he: ​​ספירת התפארת היא הספירה הרביעית לפי החלוקה העיקרית של הספירות לחמש (כתר חכמה בינה תפארת ומלכות) והיא מקבילה לבחינה ג' של האור הישר, הוא 'אור חסדים בהארת החכמה', כלומר עיקרו אור החסדים (הנמשך מרצון הנבראים להידבק בבורא) של הבינה, אך מתעורר בו גם רצון מסוים לקבל את אור הבורא, והוא מושך חלק מאור החכמה, האור העליון.

description.en: Tikkunei Zohar is a section of the Zohar attributed to the second-century tannaitic Sage Rabbi Shimon bar Yoḥai. It comprises a collection of seventy sermons, called Tikkunim, or “Rectifications,” on the opening word of the Torah, bereshit. Tikkunei Zohar differs in its style from the other sections of the Zohar, but it is considered the more profound and loftier work, which is why many kabbalists over the generations have studied it as a separate work in itself.

After the [constriction](/topics/constriction) ([*tzimtzum*](/topics/tzimtzum1)), when the [light](/topics/light2) of [*Ein Sof*](/topics/ein-sof1) is removed from all four levels, as is known, its trace nevertheless remains in every level, a form of the [light](/topics/light2) of [*Ein Sof*](/topics/ein-sof1) it contained before the [constriction](/topics/constriction) (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 2, Q & A 72). 

What are these “traces,” outside of the context of [constriction](/topics/constriction)?
Know that this trace of themselves that the lights leave behind after their departure is the kernel and the root for engendering a second [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) from it. For each effect emerges and is engendered by its cause in this manner, and thus all the lights in the worlds are drawn forth to the lower ones. They themselves are transferred from cause to the effect engendered by it, like the spark of a soul that is transferred from father to son, and which then remains permanently fixed in the son’s soul, as explained in *Or Penimi*, v. 4, section 82:3. This must be understood and kept in mind, for it is the key to understanding the factor that compels the effect to devolve from its cause, in the whole [devolvement](/topics/devolvement) of the emergence of the *partzufin* and the worlds from one another, from beginning to end (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 4, Q & A 65).

*Tzelem* (the letters *tzadi-lamed-mem*) is the [returning light](/topics/returning-light1) that rises over the incorporation of the lower [feminine waters](/topics/feminine-waters2) in the [partition](/topics/partition2) and the [opacity](/topics/opacity) ([*ovyut*](/topics/ovyut)) in the higher one. It [enclothes](/topics/enclothe) the ten [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) of [direct light](/topics/direct-light1) from that [fusion](/topics/fusion-through-collision), which are the [brains](/topics/brains2) themselves. This [returning light](/topics/returning-light1) is considered an actual expression of the higher one, for it emerged over the [partition](/topics/partition2) and the [opacity](/topics/opacity) of the higher one. However, the higher one does not engage in a [fusion](/topics/fusion-through-collision) for the sake of the lower one from its own self, but only from its externality – that is, it awakens the trace of [immaturity](/topics/immaturity1) that remains in it from its stage of [immaturity](/topics/immaturity1), which corresponds to the [feminine waters](/topics/feminine-waters2) that ascended to it. Nor does it do so from its own [partition](/topics/partition2) and [opacity](/topics/opacity) of its level, but from the lowest part of the level, as is known. It therefore follows that the higher one has no need for this measure of [returning light](/topics/returning-light1), and therefore this [returning light](/topics/returning-light1) descends with the ten [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) of the [brains](/topics/brains2) to the lower one, where it also [enclothes](/topics/enclothe) its [brains](/topics/brains2), just as it [enclothed](/topics/enclothe) them when they emerged in the higher place. Yet the lower one does not take them in its upper level, as they emerged in the higher one. Rather, it must descend twice in the higher one itself (see Answer 37), at which point it is fitting to be [enclothed](/topics/enclothe) within the lower one. One descent is called the *mem* of *tzelem*, while the second descent is called the *lamed* of *tzelem*. At the *mem* it diminishes to an expression of [*Ḥesed*](/topics/hesed), [*Gevura*](/topics/gevura), and [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), while at the *lamed* it diminishes to an expression of [*Netzaḥ*](/topics/netzah), [*Hod*](/topics/hod1), and [*Yesod*](/topics/yesod1). It subsequently expands in the lower one, and this expansion itself, within the lower one, is called the *tzadi* of *tzelem* (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 11, Q & A 56).

The constriction refers to a diminishing of the divine light. This constriction does not constitute a change in the divine light itself, as the Creator bestows His light constantly and fully. Rather, any constriction of the light is the result of a change in the created vessels formed of the will to receive. In order for constriction to take place, the vessel is modified through the placement of a [partition](/topics/partition2) upon it so that it is prevented from receiving the light. There are two types of constriction in the process of creation, the first constriction (in which a [partition](/topics/partition2) is placed upon the vessel), and the [second constriction](/topics/second-constriction).

The [will to receive](/topics/will-to-receive) in an emanated being is its vessel (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 1, Q & A 25). However, from the first [constriction](/topics/constriction) ([*tzimtzum*](/topics/tzimtzum1)), the [returning light](/topics/returning-light1) is the vessel.

The will to receive is closely linked to the concept of [opacity](/topics/opacity). This concept denotes thickness, materiality, or darkness, as opposed to purity, clarity, and spirituality. In kabbalistic terminology, this expresses the quality of the vessel, which is the will to receive. It is considered thick and dark because it is the antithesis of the eternal divine light, the essence of which is entirely giving. A greater will to receive is regarded as having greater opacity, while a vessel that contains a lesser will to receive is regarded as being more pure. This is because the greater the will to receive that a vessel acquires, the more it is distanced from the Creator and His light and the more material and dark it becomes.

The world of *nekudim* is the second of the worlds of [*Adam Kadmon*](/topics/adam-kadmon2). It is called by this name because the spiritual [levels](/topics/level) within it are called *nekudot*, or points. In this context, the *nekuda* refers to [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1), the fourth [level](/topics/level), after the first [constriction](/topics/constriction) ([*tzimtzum*](/topics/tzimtzum1)) occurred. As a result of this constriction, [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) is only a black point without any light whatsoever.Then,as a result of the [second constriction](/topics/second-constriction) ([*tzimtzum*](/topics/tzimtzum1)), [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) and the [partition](/topics/partition2) that is upon it became intermingled within all the [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) and are then present in all the [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot). As a result of this intermingling, there are ten *nekudot*, or ten *Malkhuyot* with [partitions](/topics/partition2) because the [level](/topics/level) of [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) with its [partition](/topics/partition2) is present in each of the ten [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot). This contrasts with the preceding worlds, in which there was only one [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) and one [partition](/topics/partition2). The world of *nekudim* is also called the “world of breaking,” or the “world of chaos,” because the shattering of the vessels occurred in this world.

The world of *tikkun*, or rectification, refers to the four worlds of [*Atzilut*](/topics/atzilut) ([Emanation](/topics/atzilut)), [*Beria*](/topics/beria1) ([Creation](/topics/beria1)), [*Yetzira*](/topics/yetzira1) ([Formation](/topics/yetzira1)), and [*Asiya*](/topics/asiya2) ([Action](/topics/asiya2)) in which a rectification occurs for the shattering of the vessels. This shattering occurred as a result of the second [constriction](/topics/constriction) ([*tzimtzum*](/topics/tzimtzum1)) and the ensuing processes, which caused a discrepancy between the vessels and the lights. The world of *tikkun* differs from the worlds that came before it primarily in two ways: First, in contrast to the previous worlds, in which the [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) are structured on a single line or column, in the world of *tikkun* the [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) are arranged in the form of three lines: *ḥesed,* kindness, to the right, *din*, judgment, to the left, and *raḥamim*, mercy, in the middle. This is referred to as the “rectification of lines.” Second, the world of *tikkun* contains the *parsa* (separation), which is formed as a result of the ascent of [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) in [second constriction](/topics/second-constriction) ([*tzimtzum*](/topics/tzimtzum1)). This ascent allows for combinations between the [levels](/topics/level) and the drawing forth of various lights at different times.

The name of the fifth and highest of the five [levels](/topics/level) of the soul,[*nefesh*](/topics/nefesh), [*ruaḥ*](/topics/ruah1), [*neshama*](/topics/neshama2), [*ḥaya*](/topics/haya1), and [*yeḥida*](/topics/yehida1). These five [levels](/topics/level) of the soul correspond to the five primary *sefirot*, [*Keter*](/topics/keter1), [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), [*Bina*](/topics/bina3), [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), and [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1), as well as the five worlds, [*Adam Kadmon*](/topics/adam-kadmon2), [*Atzilut*](/topics/atzilut), [*Beria*](/topics/beria1), [*Yetzira*](/topics/yetzira1), and [*Asiya*](/topics/asiya2). The concept of the five [levels](/topics/level) of the soul relates to five qualities of supernal light which illuminate people as well as the [levels](/topics/level) of broader reality. [*Yeḥida*](/topics/yehida1) is the light that parallels the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of [*Keter*](/topics/keter1) and the world of [*Adam Kadmon*](/topics/adam-kadmon2), and it illuminates the body of a person or a [level](/topics/level) only after the illumination of the four lower [levels](/topics/level), [*nefesh*](/topics/nefesh), [*ruaḥ*](/topics/ruah1), [*neshama*](/topics/neshama2), and [*ḥaya*](/topics/haya1).
The [light](/topics/light2) enclothed in the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of [*Keter*](/topics/keter1) is called *yeḥida* (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 2, Q & A 31).

Literally, “something from nothing,” *yesh me’ayin* refers to the formation of the will to receive, an entity that is entirely new and has never existed before. More specifically, this term is used in reference to the creation of the will to receive, which is the raw material of existence and the vessel through which the supernal light that emanates from the Creator’s essence is received and becomes manifest. Since the will to receive is meaningless in relation to God, who lacks nothing and has no need to receive anything, the will to receive is considered a creation ex nihilo, an entirely new creation. By contrast, the [*shefa*](/topics/shefa1) that emanates from the Creator to the created beings is referred to as *yesh miyesh*, literally, “something from something,” since it is drawn from the Creator’s essence.
description.he: בריאת "יש מאין" היא התהוות של משהו חדש לגמרי. דבר זה נאמר על בריאת הרצון לקבל, שהוא חומר המציאות, הכלי שעל ידו מתגלה שפע האור הא-להי. בריאת הרצון לקבל נקראת "יש מאין", מפני שבבורא עצמו אין מקום לדבר על רצון לקבל, שהרי אין בו חסרון או צורך כל שהוא. לעומת זאת, השפע שנמשך מן הבורא לנבראים נחשב "יש מיש", שהרי הוא נמשך מן הישות של הבורא.

description.en: Literally, “something from something,” or an entity that emanates from something that already exists, *yesh miyesh* is used to refer to the [*shefa*](/topics/shefa1) that is drawn from the Creator’s essence to all created beings. This is in contrast to the creation of the will to receive, which is a creation ex nihilo, or [*yesh me’ayin*](/topics/yesh-meayin), literally, “something from nothing.” Since the will to receive is meaningless in relation to God Himself, as He lacks nothing and has no need to receive anything, the will to receive is considered a creation ex nihilo, an entirely new creation.

The [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of *Yesod* is the ninth of the ten [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot). When the [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) are divided into the five primary [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) – [*Keter*](/topics/keter1), [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), [*Bina*](/topics/bina3), [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), and [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) – *Yesod* is encompassed in the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1).  *Yesod* is the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) that represents the end of the middle line or column, the line of [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1). Accordingly, *Yesod* is a unique aspect of the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1) and also exists in parallel in the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1), which receives the lights of [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1). *Yesod*, which means “Foundation,” is named thus because it includes the “foundations” of its [level](/topics/level), meaning the various lights within that [level](/topics/level). It then transmits these lights to the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) below it, so that *Yesod* serve as the foundation for the existence of the feminine aspect of the [level](/topics/level). In the structure of [*partzufim*](/topics/partzuf), which correlate to the human body, the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of *Yesod* represents the sexual reproductive organs.

The world of *Yetzira* is the third of the four worlds (after the supernal world of *Adam Kadmon*) that emanate and descend from one another in the process of creation. Some maintain that its name derives from the Hebrew words for form, *tzura*, or image, *tziyur*, since it is a kind of image or pattern for the final and fourth world, [*Asiya*](/topics/asiya2). Each of the worlds corresponds to one of the five primary [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot). The world of *Yetzira* corresponds to the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1) or the third [level](/topics/level) of creation. The created beings that dwell in this [level](/topics/level) are the angels called *ḥayot*.

*Yisrael Sabba* and *Tevuna* is a double [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) with a male and female aspect. It was generated in the world of [*Atzilut*](/topics/atzilut) after the second constriction ([*tzimtzum*](/topics/tzimtzum1)), which separated every [level](/topics/level) of reality into two parts. The upper part of each [level](/topics/level) contains the [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) of [*Keter*](/topics/keter1) and [*Hokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), while the lower part of the [level](/topics/level) contains [*Bina*](/topics/bina3)>, [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), and [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1). This split began in the third [level](/topics/level) of [*Adam Kadmon*](/topics/adam-kadmon2), which is the [level](/topics/level) of [*Bina*](/topics/bina3)> of [*Adam Kadmon*](/topics/adam-kadmon2). The part of the [level](/topics/level) of [*Bina*](/topics/bina3)> that remains above the split and so contains the first three [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) of the original [level](/topics/level) – [*Keter*](/topics/keter1), [*Hokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), and [*Bina*](/topics/bina3)> – is called *Abba VeImma Ila’in*, or “the lofty Father and Mother.” The part of the [level](/topics/level) below the split consists of the seven lower [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot), [*Hesed*](/topics/hesed), [*Gevura*](/topics/gevura), [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), [*Netzah*](/topics/netzah), [*Hod*](/topics/hod1), [*Yesod*](/topics/yesod1) and [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) – and is called *Yisrael Sabba* and *Tevuna*.  The reason this lower part is called by this name is because the primary purpose of this [level](/topics/level) is to pass along the supernal light flowing through *Abba VeImma Ila’in* to the [*partzufim*](/topics/partzuf) below *Yisrael Sabba* and *Tevuna*. Those lower [*partzufim*](/topics/partzuf) are [*Ze’er Anpin*](/topics/zeer-anpin1) and *Nukba*. [*Ze’er Anpin*](/topics/zeer-anpin1) is referred to as *Yisrael*, and therefore, the corresponding aspect of the [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) above it is called *Yisrael Sabba* (Grandfather *Yisrael*). The word *Tevuna* comes from the language of *ben* and *bat*, which means “son” and “daughter.” This indicates the idea of this [level](/topics/level) sharing its light to the “children,” [*Ze’er Anpin*](/topics/zeer-anpin1) and *Nukba*, which are the “offspring” of [*Bina*](/topics/bina3)>, the “mother.”

The [seven lower ones](/topics/seven-lower-ones) of [*Abba* and *Imma*](/topics/abba-and-imma), that is, their ear nose and mouth, are called *Yisrael* *Sabba* and *Tevuna*. Initially, at the time of the [fusion](/topics/fusion-through-collision) of the [gaze](/topics/gaze1) of the [eyes](/topics/eyes4) of [*Abba* and *Imma*](/topics/abba-and-imma) towards one another, *Yisrael* *Sabba* and *Tevuna* and [*Abba* and *Imma*](/topics/abba-and-imma) are united in a single [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1). Subsequently, however, when [*Abba* and *Imma*](/topics/abba-and-imma) return to a back-to-back [fusion](/topics/fusion-through-collision), *Yisrael* *Sabba* and *Tevuna* separate from them and emerge as a special [head](/topics/head2) at the level of the ear nose and mouth, becoming a distinct [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 7, Q & A 50).
See the entries on [*Ze*’*er* *Anpin*](/topics/zeer-anpin1) and [*Nukba*](/topics/nukba).

*Ze*’*er* *Anpin* means “the small face,” for the [light of *Ḥokhma*](/topics/light-of-hokhma) is called “the light of the face,” in the mystical meaning of the verse: “A man’s wisdom illuminates his face” (Ecclesiastes 8:1). In the same vein, the general [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) of the [*Keter*](/topics/keter1) in the world of [*Atzilut*](/topics/atzilut) ([Emanation](/topics/atzilut)) is called [*Arikh Anpin*](/topics/arikh-anpin1), or “the long face,” because it contains the essence of the [light of *Ḥokhma*](/topics/light-of-hokhma). Consequently, the third level, whose essence is only [light of giving](/topics/light-of-giving) that is drawn from [*Bina*](/topics/bina3), but which also contains illumination from  [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) (albeit not the essence of the [light of *Ḥokhma*](/topics/light-of-hokhma)), is called by this name of “the small face,” or *Ze*’*er* *Anpin*. The reason is that the [light](/topics/light2) of its [face](/topics/partzuf1) is small and slight in relation to the first level (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 2, Q & A 24).

Praise of God involves expressing gratitude and admiration directly to Him in diverse situations and contexts. While the book of Psalms contains numerous instances of such praise, similar expressions can also be found in other books of the Bible and subsequent religious texts.
description.he: תהילת אלוקים הוא הצהרת הערכה כלפי הקב"ה במגוון מצבים והקשרים. הצהרות כאלה מצויות באופן מרוכז בספר תהילים אך גם נפוצות בספרים אחרים בתנ"ך ובטקסטים דתיים מאוחרים יותר.

description.en: “The Four Expressions of Redemption” refers to four expressions from God’s speech to Moses in Exodus 6:6–7, in which God promises to redeem the Israelites from their enslavement in Egypt. God uses four phrases to describe the process: “I will take you out,” “I will save you,” I will redeem you,” and “I will take you.” Some consider a phrase in the following verse, “I will bring you,” to be a fifth expression of redemption.
description.he: ״ארבע לשונות של גאולה״ הן הביטויים שאמר האל למשה (ספר שמות, פרק ו׳, פסוקים ו-ח) המבטאים את שלבי גאולת עם ישראל מעבדות מצרים. לדעת חלק מהדעות בתלמוד הירושלמי - הן מהוות את מקור המנהג של שתיית ארבע כוסות יין בליל הסדר. ארבע הלשונות הן: ״והוצאתי״ - ״והצלתי״, ״וגאלתי״ - ״ולקחתי״ - ויש שביארו שישנה גם לשון גאולה חמישית - ״והבאתי״.

description.en: In Judaism, priests are descendants of the biblical character [Aaron](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/aaron?tab=sources). In the Bible, they are charged with doing the ritual work in the [Mishkan](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/mishkan?tab=sources) and later the Temples, under the leadership of a [high priest](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/high-priest?tab=sources). In Temple times, priests were also entitled to certain gifts and portions of sacrifices. Today, some people of priestly descent recite a special blessing in the synagogue and are careful to avoid contact with corpses, among other responsibilities and restrictions.

Mashiach (the Messiah) — literally "anointed one" — generally refers to a savior or liberator figure believed to be a future redeemer of Jews, who ushers in the messianic era. Generations of Jewish texts debate what the messianic era entails, as well as the role that belief in the Messiah should play in Jewish practice. In the Bible, the word *mashiach* is used to refer to kings or high priests, selected by God and anointed with oil.
description.he: משיח - דמות מרכזית בשליחות אלוהים, הנחשבת כגואלת העתידית של עם ישראל, פותחת את העידן המשיחי ומביאה לבסוף לשלום עולמי. מקורות היהדות לאורך הדורות מתווכחים על אופיים של ימות המשיח ועל התפקיד שהאמונה במשיח צריכה למלא. כל המקורות שותפים לציפייה למשיח ולגאולה שמלווה את העם היהודי דורות רבים ומוזכרת פעמים רבות בתפילה ובשאר המקורות. בתנ"ך, המילה *משיח* משמשת להתייחסות למלכים או כוהנים גדולים, שנבחרו על ידי אלוהים ונמשחו בשמן.

description.en: Prophecy features throughout in Jewish literature, most prominently with prophets who appear throughout the Bible. The [Talmud](https://www.sefaria.org/Megillah.14a.4?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en) counts 55 people recorded in the Bible who prophesied on behalf of Israel, and [notes](https://www.sefaria.org/Megillah.14a.11?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en) that there were many additional prophets whose prophecies may not have been recorded.

Miracles feature throughout the Jewish textual tradition. Supernatural events appear throughout the Bible, including the [ten plagues](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/the-ten-plagues?sort=Relevance&tab=sources), the [splitting of the sea](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/splitting-of-the-red-sea?tab=sources), and when the walls of [Jericho](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/jericho?tab=sources) fell, among others. Miracles feature in later rabbinic texts as well, and ancient through contemporary works analyze the nature and significance of miracles.
Sitra Achra (literally "other side") is a kabbalistic term refering to the realm of evil or impure forces, in opposition to the Sitra D’Kedushah, the side of holiness.

The prohibition against worshipping other gods is the second of the [Ten Commandments](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/the-ten-commandments?sort=Relevance&tab=sources), and one of the seven Noahide Laws, the laws the rabbis understood to be incumbent upon all non-Jews as well. That is, ideally, all the world recognizes God as the Creator and Master of the Universe. Nevertheless, worship of other gods is central to the dramatic relationship between God and Israel throughout the Tanakh (Hebrew Bible). Defining idolatry and ensuring that one does not inadvertently worship an idol or other god  is the core of the mishnaic and talmudic tractates of [Avodah Zarah](https://www.sefaria.org/Avodah_Zarah?tab=contents).

description.en: Written as part of Rambam's Commentary on the Mishnah to the tenth chapter of tractate Sanhedrin, Rambam's 13 Principles of Faith articulate the fundamental tenets of Jewish faith. Rambam wanted to help people avoid errors of faith. The 13 Principles are first found as declarative statements of faith ("I believe with perfect faith that...") in the Venice Hagaddah of 1566 CE and most popularly known from the poem, Yigdal, from around 1300 CE.

description.he: ארבע אותיות אלה (שבאנגלית נכתבות YHVH) מייצגות את 'השם המפורש' של אלוהים. מסורת יהודית עתיקה אוסרת להגות בקול את השם, ולכן אופן ההגייה המקורי של מילה זו אינו ברור.  במקום זאת, ישנן מגוון של מילים שמחליפות את השם המפורש כמו "אדוניי" ו"השם" בהתאם להקשר.
description.en: The Hebrew letters ‘yud,’ ‘hey,’ ‘vav,’ and ‘hey’ (in English, YHVH) form what is known as the Tetragrammaton, or God’s four-letter name. Given the longstanding Jewish prohibition against speaking God’s name aloud, the word’s original pronunciation is unclear, and it is traditionally not pronounced as written. Instead, a variety of substitutes are used - like “Adonai” (“My Lord”) and “Hashem” (“The Name”) - depending on the context.

Midrash is a form of literature that interprets and elaborates upon biblical texts, mostly compiled from the 5th century CE through the medieval period. Books in this category generally share common methods of interpretation, like filling in gaps in biblical stories. Sections of midrash appear frequently throughout the [Talmud](https://www.sefaria.org/texts/Talmud/Bavli).

categoryDescription.en: Practices and characteristics valued in the Jewish tradition.
categoryDescription.he: מידות ומעשים בעלי ערך במסורת היהודית.

description.en: Beit Midrash, meaning "house of study," is a dedicated space for Torah learning. Unlike a synagogue, which primarily serves as a venue for prayer services, a Beit Midrash focuses on in-depth study.
description.he: פירושו של הצירוף בית מדרש הוא "מקום לימוד". בית המדרש הוא מקום המשמש ללימוד תורה בשונה מבית כנסת המיועד לתפילה.

categoryDescription.en: Practices and characteristics valued in the Jewish tradition.
categoryDescription.he: מידות ומעשים בעלי ערך במסורת היהודית.

description.en: Knowing God (Yediat HaShem) refers to how a person gains better awareness and understanding of God.  There are many ways that people enhance their knowledge of God, such as through meditation or asking philosophical questions.
description.he: ידיעת השם משמעה שכלול ההבנה השכלית של האדם את האלוהים והגברת המודעות לנוכחותו. יש דרכים רבות שהאדם יכול לחזק את ידיעת השם שלו, למשל מדיטציה או עיסוק בשאלות פילוסופיות.

description.en: The Torah is Judaism's foundational text, described as given by God to the Israelites at Mount Sinai. The five books that make up the Torah are [Genesis](https://www.sefaria.org/Genesis?tab=contents), [Exodus](https://www.sefaria.org/Exodus?tab=contents), [Leviticus](https://www.sefaria.org/Leviticus?tab=contents), [Numbers](https://www.sefaria.org/Numbers?tab=contents), and [Deuteronomy](https://www.sefaria.org/Deuteronomy?tab=contents). They tell of the origins and development of the Israelite nation and present the foundational laws of Judaism.

Rest is the abstention from creative work. After the six days of creation, God rested, and the fourth of the Ten Commandments — Shabbat — is to cease from creative work and rest just as God did. The Torah also commands that the land of Israel be left to lie fallow every seventh year in observance of [shemittah](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/shemitah?tab=sources). Rest is also required on holidays. While rest is the means of renewing our bodies and souls, tradition also recognizes it as a taste of the world to come.

Peace is a value that features in a variety of contexts in the Jewish textual tradition. Jewish books throughout the ages extol the value of peace, argue about the best means to achieving it, and grapple with attitudes toward violence in the pursuit of peace.
description.he: שלום הוא ערך מרכזי בתפיסת העולם היהודית ומופיע במגוון הקשרים במקורות היהדות. ברכת השלום חותמת את תפילת העמידה, את תפילת הקדיש והמילה "שלום" היא אחת משמותיו של האל. בספרי היהדות לאורך הדורות השלום נתפס כמצב אידיאלי והרמוני כאשר המחלוקת לגביו היא כיצד ניתן להשיגו, עד כמה נכון לוותר ולהתפשר עבורו וכיצד להכריע כאשר יש קונפליקט בין האמת והשלום.

description.en: Middot literally means “measures,” but it’s typically translated as “character traits,” because a person is defined—or measured—by their character traits.
description.he: מלבד המובן המילולי הפשוט של מידות רוחב או אורך, למילה מידות יש משמעות של תכונות אופי, מפני שהאדם מוגדר – או נמדד – לפי תכונות האופי שלו.

description.en: Bal Tashchit is the Hebrew term for “do not destroy” and prohibits unnecessarily destroying or disposing of useful things. Although the Bible specifically mentions the senseless destruction of fruit trees, the Rabbis understood the prohibition to include other types of senseless waste.
description.he: בל תשחית (מלשון השחתה) הוא האיסור על הרס סתמי או השלכה ללא צורך של חפצים. אף שבתורה נזכר איסור זה רק ביחס לעצי פרי, חז"ל הבינו שהוא כולל גם סוגים נוספים של השחתה ללא צורך.

description.en: In Judaism, visiting the sick (bikur cholim) is an important act of loving-kindness (gemilut hasadim) that requires one to provide physical or emotional support to someone who isn't feeling well.
description.he: ביקור חולים הוא רכיב חשוב בתוך המצווה הכללית של גמילות חסדים. הן תמיכה רגשית והן תמיכה פיזית באדם שחש ברע נחשבות לביקור חולים.

description.en: Strength is a trait and value discussed at length in Jewish sources. Biblical stories feature physically strong heroes, such as Samson in the book of Judges. Rabbinic texts  analyze the merits of different types of strength and how they should be valued and prioritized.

Gratitude, or the concept of being thankful, is prevalent throughout Jewish texts. It is the theme of the first prayer uttered upon waking up in the morning, Modeh Ani (“I give thanks”), and is a value that drives countless other Jewish practices, traditions, and customs.
Welcoming guests (hachnasat orchim) is an important act of loving-kindness (gemilut chasadim). Welcoming guests also involves housing and feeding guests—with a friendly and welcoming disposition.
description.he: הכנסת אורחים היא רכיב חשוב בתוך המצווה הכללית של גמילות חסדים. מלבד פתיחת הבית לאורח, הכנסת אורחים כוללת לינה ומזון, כל זאת מתוך אהבה ובסבר פנים יפות.

description.en: Gratitude, or the concept of being thankful, is prevalent throughout Jewish texts. It is the theme of the first prayer uttered upon waking up in the morning, Modeh Ani (“I give thanks”), and is a value that drives countless other Jewish practices, traditions, and customs.
description.he: הכרת הטוב היא עמדה מוסרית אשר גורסת כי מחובתו של האדם להכיר בתועלת שקיבל. הכרת הטוב מתבטאת בדרך כלל ברגש, בדיבור ולפעמים אף במעשה באופן שהאדם מחזיר טובה למי שהטיב איתו. עמדה זו נחשבת לאבן יסוד ביהדות והתפתחו בעם ישראל הלכות רבות הקשורות לנושא זה. בפרט תפילת ״מודה אני״, הנאמרת בעת קימה בבוקר, מבטאת באופן תמציתי רעיון זה בקשר שבין אדם למקום.

description.en: Renewal is a concept that can involve revitalizing, reinvigorating, or returning to an original state. In Judaism, the term can be used to refer to a specific 20th-century Jewish movement, but  is also a concept found throughout biblical and rabbinic literature. The idea is particularly prevalent throughout chasidic texts, which emphasize performing routine commandments as if it were one’s first time performing them.
description.he: התחדשות היא רעיון חזרת המצב לקדמותו לאחר שינוי, או היווספות פרטים ומאפיינים חדשים לדבר קיים. ביהדות, המושג יכול להתייחס לתנועה יהודית ספציפית במאה ה-20 אשר שמה דגש על הרעננות והחיוניות בחוויה האלוהית, או למושג שמופיע רבות בתנ״ך ובספרות חז״ל. ניתן למצוא את רעיון ההתחדשות גם בספרי חסידות רבים המדגישים את חשיבות יישום רעיון זה בקיום המצוות המעשיות.

description.en: Friendship is a value discussed throughout Jewish literature in a variety of contexts. Stories of friendship are present throughout the Bible, and rabbinic sources analyze the parameters, obligations, and significance of friendship.

Freedom is a concept prevalent throughout Jewish texts. The term is often associated with the biblical story of the Exodus, in which the Israelites were freed from slavery in Egypt, as well as with the ability to perform good deeds and make positive choices.
description.he: חירות היא מושג מורכב ורב-גוני ביהדות אשר משמעותו התפתחה במרוצת השנים. חשיבותה של החירות ביהדות מודגשת היטב ברעיון התשובה ובסיפור יציאת מצרים, בו מתואר כיצד עם ישראל כולו יצא מעבדות והפך לעם חופשי. בנוסף, מושג החירות קשור למושג הבחירה החופשית של האדם והיחס בין ידיעת האל מראש את העתיד לבין חירותו של האדם לפעול על פי מצפונו.

description.en: The commandment to honor one’s parents is the fifth of the Ten Commandments [(Exodus 20:12)](https://www.sefaria.org/Exodus.20.12?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en). Rabbinic sources describe the commandment as on par with revering God: just as we acknowledge the gifts that God gives us, we must also show gratitude for the gift of life that our parents gave us.
description.he: מצוות כיבוד הורים היא הדיבר החמישי בעשרת הדיברות (שמות כ, יב ודברים ה, טז). מקורות פרשניים רבים משווים את הציווי על כיבוד ההורים  לחובת הכבוד לאלוהים. ערך מרכזי נוסף שמצווה זו מבטאת הוא הכרת הטוב לפיו מוטלת עלינו החובה להכיר טובה להורינו על מתנת החיים שהעניקו לנו.

description.en: Atonement, or kapparah in Hebrew, is the process of bringing about forgiveness for a sin. In the Jewish textual tradition, atonement may be achieved through repentance, prayer, sacrifice, punishment, the rituals of [Yom Kippur](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/yom-kippur?sort=Relevance&tab=sources), and other methods.

Teaching is a central value in Judaism that features in a variety of context. The biblical patriarch Abraham is instructed to teach his descendants the ways of justice and righteousness, for examples, and rabbinic literature analyzes the responsibilities of parents to ensure that their children receive an education.

A machloket is a dispute between two different interpretations of Torah law. Although these disagreements can be incredibly destructive, disputes like those between Hillel and Shammai are considered constructive and known as “disagreements for the sake of heaven.”
description.he: מחלוקת היא ויכוח בין שתי פרשנויות שונות להלכה מסוימת. אף שהוויכוחים הללו עלולים להיות הרסניים, מחלוקות כמו אלה של הלל ושמאי נזכרות לחיוב ומתוארות כ"מחלוקת לשם שמיים".

description.en: Forgiveness is a value discussed throughout the Jewish textual tradition. It is particularly associated with the holidays of [Rosh Hashanah](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/rosh-hashanah?sort=Relevance&tab=sources) and [Yom Kippur](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/yom-kippur?tab=sources), and the days that lead up to them.

Yirat Shamayim translates as “fear of heaven,” but is understood to apply to God too. Yirat Shamayim is an important and central spiritual quality that includes having both a fear and an awe of God and creation.
description.he: על פי רוב כוונת הביטוי יראת שמיים היא יראה מפני האל. יראת שמיים היא תכונה רוחנית חשובה ומרכזית המאגדת בתוכה פחד ויראה מן האל ובריאתו.

description.en: Avodat HaShem (service of God) is the approach to worshiping God and fulfilling the religious and spiritual obligations that are defined in the Torah.
description.he: עבודת השם כוללת סגידה לאל ומילוי החובות הדתיות והרוחניות שבתורה.

description.en: The word tzedakah comes from the Hebrew word for tzedek (justice) and is charity given to the poor in pursuit of a just, ethical society. Whereas acts of loving-kindness (gemilut chasidim) can be done for the rich or poor, living or dead, tzedakah is only for the living poor.
description.he: המילה צדקה גזורה מהמילה "צדק", והיא נדבה הניתנת לעניים מתוך שאיפה לבנות חברה מוסרית וצודקת. לעומת גמילות חסדים שאותה אפשר לעשות לעשירים ולעניים, למתים ולחיים, צדקה ניתנת רק לעני שנמצא בחיים.

description.en: A kehillah is a community of individuals who come together for a common goal or purpose. Although a kehillah can become a chaotic mass—such as during the sin of the Golden Calf—when positive character traits are combined in pursuit of a goal, much good can be achieved.
description.he: קהילה היא מקבץ של פרטים המתאגדים לשם מטרה או יעד משותפים. אף שקהילה יכולה להגיע למצב הרסני, כפי שמוכיח היטב חטא העגל, כאשר תכונות אופי חיוביות רבות משתלבות יחד למטרה מסוימת, אפשר להפיק מכך טובה גדולה.

description.en: While joy itself can be a form of serving God, in some instances, it can also be a human response to divine action or of being close to God. It may also be a divine response to humanity's fulfillment of God's will. The Torah also commands Jews to rejoice in some contexts.

Tikkun means “repair” or “mend” and is used alongside the word olam (world) to express the Jewish responsibility to “repair the world.” Tikkun also refers to specific texts read on various holidays, including the seventh day of Passover and on Shavuot.
description.he: הביטוי תיקון עולם מסמל את האחריות היהודית לשכלול המוסריות האנושית. המונח "תיקון" לבדו קשור בטקסטים מסוימים הנקראים בכמה מועדים, דוגמת שביעי של פסח ושבועות.

description.en: The word "teshuvah" literally means “return” and is best translated as "repentance." Teshuvah is presented in Jewish sources as a gift from God because it allows one to return to the path of righteousness. Although it can be done at any time, Yom Kippur is the Jewish holiday most associated with repentance.
description.he: המונח תשובה כוונתו שיבה אל דרכי האל. במקורות היהודיים נתפסת התשובה כמתנה מאלוהים, מכיוון שהיא מאפשרת לאדם לשוב ולדבוק בדרכי הטוב והיושר. אף שתשובה היא דבר שאפשר לעשות בכל עת, יום הכיפורים הוא המועד המוכר ביותר למטרה זו.

description.en: Torah study involves the study of sacred Jewish texts, like the Torah, Mishnah, Talmud, and works of midrash, kabbalah, and Jewish thought. It is considered central to religious practice, with blessings acknowledging the commandment to engage in Torah study and thanking God for giving the Torah featured at the beginning of daily liturgy. The subject, form, and nature of Torah study vary between individuals and communities.
description.he: לימוד תורה הוא חלק אינטגרלי מהמסורת היהודית. הוא כרוך בלימוד הטקסטים היהודיים, לרבות תנ״ך, משנה, תלמוד, ספרי קבלה ומחשבת ישראל, ועוד. לימוד התורה נחשב למצווה ומוערך מאוד בתרבות היהודית כאמצעי לחיבור עם האל, להעמקת הידע וההבנה של האדם ולשיפור התנהגותו המוסרית והאתית. מקור המצווה  הוא במספר פסוקים בספר דברים: ״וְלִמַּדְתֶּם אֹתָם אֶת בְּנֵיכֶם לְדַבֵּר בָּם בְּשִׁבְתְּךָ בְּבֵיתֶךָ וּבְלֶכְתְּךָ בַדֶּרֶךְ וּבְשָׁכְבְּךָ וּבְקוּמֶךָ״ (דברים, יא, יט), ״וּלְמַדְתֶּם אֹתָם וּשְׁמַרְתֶּם לַעֲשֹׂתָם״ (דברים, ה, א), ״וְשִׁנַּנְתָּם לְבָנֶיךָ וְדִבַּרְתָּ בָּם״ (דברים, ו, ז).

description.en: Shalom bayit describes harmony between spouses and literally means “peace in the home.” Judaism places a high priority on building a peaceful, nurturing atmosphere through acts of loving-kindness and respect in order to achieve shalom bayit.
description.he: שלום בית מתאר את היחסים הטובים בין בני זוג. ביהדות ניתנת חשיבות רבה לבניית מרחב שלו ומצמיח המביא לידי מצב תמידי של שלום בית, זאת באמצעות מעשים של גמילות חסדים וכבוד.

description.en: “Love your neighbor as yourself” (Leviticus 19:18) is the basis for a central principle known as the Golden Rule, or the concept of treating others as one wants to be treated themselves. Much commentary has been penned attempting to understand the verse’s moral message, scope, practical implications, and role in Judaism.
description.he: "ואהבת לרעך כמוך" - מילים שמגיעים מויקרא יט:יח -  הוא אחד העקרונות הידועים והמרכזיים ביהדות אשר מדגיש את חשיבות ההתייחסות לזולת באדיבות, בכבוד ובאמפתיה. הרעיון מאחורי "ואהבת לרעך כמוך" הוא שעלינו לשאוף להתייחס לאחרים כפי שהיינו רוצים שיתייחסו אלינו, באהבה, בחמלה ובהבנה. מושג זה משתקף גם במסורות דתות ומוסריות אחרות, ולעתים קרובות הוא מצוטט כעיקרון מנחה לקידום הרמוניה חברתית, שיתוף פעולה ושיח בין-דתי.

description.en: This tractate of the Mishnah contains ancient wisdom and ethics of the rabbinic sages. Traditionally, the work is studied between Passover and Shavuot. Perhaps because of the tractate’s place in the liturgical calendar, it has spawned many commentaries over the centuries.

Baseless hatred is known in Judaism as the reason that the Second Temple was destroyed. Sources throughout the Jewish library discuss the corrosive nature of baseless hatred, its legal boundaries and implications, and ways to escape its grasp.
description.he: 'שנאת חינם' ידועה בהיותה הסיבה שבגללה חרב בית המקדש השני. כיום רבים משתמשים בביטוי זה עבור שנאה לא עניינית. המקורות ברחבי הספרות היהודית דנים בשנאת החינם וברגש השנאה בכלל, בהרס שהיא עלולה להוביל אליו, בגבולותיה, השלכותיה ההלכתיות ובדרכים להימלט מאחיזתה.

description.en: The Torah commands [“Justice, justice you shall pursue”](https://www.sefaria.org/Deuteronomy.16.20?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en) as a condition for inhabiting the land of Israel. The Torah further commands specific measures to be put in place in order to establish just societies, including just courts and fair and honest weights and measures. Several biblical prophets critique those who prioritize ritual practice but ignore the Torah’s imperatives to act justly, and sources throughout the rabbinic tradition discuss and analyze the requirements and parameters of justice.

A tzaddik is someone who embodies tzedek, or righteousness, in order to overcome their surroundings in order to serve as a source of inspiration and spiritual help for others. In Hasidic literature, the tzaddik often pleads with God on behalf of the Jewish people.
description.he: המילה צדיק גזורה מהמילה "צדק". צדיק הוא אדם המגלם בתוכו רמה יוצאת דופן של צדק ויושרה ובאופן זה משמש מקור השראה וסיוע רוחני לאחרים. בספרות החסידית פעמים רבות הצדיק מתחנן לאלוהים בשם העם היהודי.

description.en: Usually a reference to religious martyrdom.

categoryDescription.en: The numerous details of Halakhah, Jewish law.

description.en: Darchei Shalom (lit. "Ways of Peace") refers to good relations among neighbors.

children.en: Mutual Responsibility of the Jewish People

description.en: Gematria is the practice of assigning numerical values to Hebrew letters. Throughout rabbinic and Jewish literature, Gematria is used as a tool for interpreting biblical texts and deriving meaning from words and phrases.

children.en: Beyond the Letter of the Law
Commandments between Man and God, and between Man and His Fellow
children.he: מצוות בין אדם למקום ובין אדם לחברו

children.en: Hermeneutical Rules through which the Torah is Interpreted

description.en: Covenants are binding commitments made between two parties. The most famous covenants in Tanakh are those that God made with Abraham, these include the ["covenant between the parts"](https://www.sefaria.org/Genesis.15.2?lang=bi&aliyot=0)  and that of [circumcision](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/circumcision?tab=sources). People too can make covenants, as was the case when Abraham made [one with Abimelekh](https://www.sefaria.org/Genesis.21.23?lang=bi&aliyot=0).

Taharah is ritual purity and contrasts to tumah, ritual impurity. While the Temples stood, one needed to be in a state of ritual purity to enter the Temple and offer a sacrifice. To attain such a status, depending on the nature of the impurity contracted, the purification process may have entailed a waiting period, sprinkling with the ashes of a [red heifer](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/parah-adumah?sort=Relevance&tab=sources), and immersion in a [mikveh](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/mikveh?sort=Relevance&tab=sources). Purity and impurity are the focus of [Seder Toharot](https://www.sefaria.org/texts/Mishnah). While most of these laws are no longer observed in the absence of the Temple, some still are.

Tzara'at is a biblical disease that involved discoloration of one's skin, home, or clothing. Once confirmed by a priest's inspection, it renders the subject ritually impure, requiring them to leave the camp for a period, undergo further inspection, and then a purification process. Tzara'at is the subject of [Leviticus 13–14](https://www.sefaria.org/Leviticus.13?lang=bi&aliyot=0). Several biblical stories have characters inflicted with tzara'at. And tzara'at is the subject of the Mishnah's tractate [Negaim](https://www.sefaria.org/Mishnah_Negaim?tab=contents).

During the Shemittah year, working the land is prohibited, produce that grows on the land takes on sacred status, and debts are forgiven. Shemittah is first mentioned in the Torah in [Exodus 23:10-11](https://www.sefaria.org/Exodus.23.10?ven=The_Contemporary_Torah,_Jewish_Publication_Society,_2006&lang=he&with=all&lang2=he).

“Bikkurim” (“first fruits”) refers to the commandment, detailed in Deuteronomy 26:1-11, to bring first fruits and grains to the Temple and give them to a priest next to the altar.
Details of the process are discussed in tractate Bikkurim, which describes the festive procession that accompanied the offering. Bkkurim is often associated with the holiday of Shavuot, since the holiday marked the beginning of the period during which bikkurim were brought.

description.en: Hatarat Nedarim (the annulment of vows) is a legal process which allows one to cancel a vow by reciting a text in the presence of three people. It is customary to perform hatarat nedarim in the days leading up to [Rosh HaShanah](https://www.sefaria.org/Rosh_Hashanah?tab=contents) or [Yom Kippur](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/yom-kippur?sort=Relevance&tab=sources), in a version of the ceremony that involves cancelling all vows taken in the past and to be taken in the future.

description.en: A neder is a vow taken voluntarily. A vow can forbid one from deriving pleasure from particular objects or actions, obligate one to perform an action in the future, or declare that an individual is becoming a [Nazirite](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/nazir?tab=sources), among other functions. Stories of vows feature throughout the Bible, and many laws relating to vows are derived from [Numbers 30](https://www.sefaria.org/Numbers.30.3?ven=The_Contemporary_Torah,_Jewish_Publication_Society,_2006&lang=en&aliyot=0).

A Nazirite, or nazir in Hebrew, is an individual who vows abstinence from wine, haircuts, and ritual impurity generated from contact with corpses. Laws relating to Nazirites are described in [Numbers 6:1-21](https://www.sefaria.org/Numbers.6.1?ven=The_Koren_Jerusalem_Bible&lang=en&with=all&lang2=en) and are the focus of tractate Nazir in the [Mishnah](https://www.sefaria.org/Mishnah_Nazir?tab=contents) and [Talmud](https://www.sefaria.org/Nazir?tab=contents).

description.en: Bedikat Chametz is the process of searching a home to ensure that it is free of chametz — that is, leavened products forbidden on Passover— performed before the holiday begins. Biur Chametz (literally, “burning of the chametz”) is the process of destroying any remaining chametz on the morning before Passover. Jewish sources abound with discussions of how exactly the chametz is to be eradicated, the timing of the process, and its spiritual significance.
description.he: בדיקת חמץ היא מצוות עשה לחפש את החמץ בליל י״ד בניסן, לילה לפני חג הפסח, על מנת לבערו בבוקר לפני חצות היום. לאחר הבדיקה, ישנו גם תהליך נוסף - ביטול החמץ, בו הבודק מכריז מילולית כי הוא מתייחס לחמץ שלו כדבר חסר ערך ומפקיר אותו. ביעור חמץ הוא מצווה להשמיד את החמץ לפני פסח לא רק במחשבה אלא גם במעשה, דרך שריפה או בכל דרך אשר הופכת אותו לבלתי ראוי לשימוש.

description.en: The jubilee (yovel) year is the 50th year in the biblical agricultural cycle and occurs after seven cycles of seven-year shemittah cycles. During the jubilee year, [a shofar is blown on Yom Kippur](https://www.sefaria.org/Leviticus.25.9?ven=The_Contemporary_Torah,_Jewish_Publication_Society,_2006&lang=he&with=all&lang2=he), land ownership resets to its original holders, and all Israelite slaves are set free. Like the [shemittah (sabbatical year)](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/shemitah?tab=sources) year, the jubilee year is one in which the land is not worked.

The service included offering daily sacrifices, cleaning and preparing the altar for sacrifice, arranging the [menorah](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/menorah1?tab=sources) for lighting, offering the [ketoret](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/incense?tab=sources), and more. Particulars of the service are discussed in detail in the [book of Leviticus](https://www.sefaria.org/Leviticus?tab=contents) and in the fifth order of the Mishnah and Talmud, [Kodashim](https://www.sefaria.org/texts/Mishnah/Seder%20Kodashim).

The Hebrew word for ritual sacrifice is “korban,” or that which is brought near — to be offered to God. The Torah, mainly in the [book of Leviticus](https://www.sefaria.org/Leviticus?tab=contents), describes different kinds of offerings for different occasions and circumstances, and the ancient rabbis discuss sacrifices in detail in the fifth order of the Mishnah, [Kodashim](https://www.sefaria.org/texts/Mishnah/Seder%20Kodashim), and later in the Talmud. Among the many kinds of sacrifices are those given in regular service to God, for giving thanks, to atone for sin, on the occasion of presenting oneself at the Temple in Jerusalem, for holidays, and more.

Monetary or physical gifts feature in a variety of contexts in Jewish sources. The Torah instructs Israelites to give donations of goods to the Temple and donations of produce and crops to priests and the needy. Giving gifts is also associated with holidays: The biblical book of Esther describes an exchange of gifts on the holiday of Purim. Later rabbinic sources also discuss the the giving of gifts as a way to fulfill the obligation to rejoice on the holidays.
description.he: מתנות כספיות או פיזיות מופיעות במגוון הקשרים במקורות היהודיים. התורה מורה לבני ישראל לתת תרומות של סחורה לבית המקדש ותרומות תוצרת ויבולים לכהנים ולנזקקים. מתן מתנות קשור גם לחגים: מגילת אסתר המקראית מתארת ​​חילופי מתנות בחג הפורים. מקורות רבנים מאוחרים יותר דנים גם במתן מתנות כדרך למילוי חובת השמחה בחגים.

description.en: The redemption of captives is a topic discussed throughout rabbinic literature. Instances of redeeming captives are found in the Bible, for example when Abraham [goes to war](https://www.sefaria.org/Genesis.14.14?ven=The_Koren_Jerusalem_Bible&lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en) with four kings in order to save his captured nephew, [Lot](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/lot?tab=sources). While sources stress the importance of redeeming captives, calling it a "[great mitzvah](https://www.sefaria.org/Bava_Batra.8b.2?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en)," other texts warn not to redeem captives [for more than their value](https://www.sefaria.org/Mishnah_Gittin.4.6?lang=bi).
description.he: פדיון שבויים היא מצווה לפיה יש להציל כל אחד ואחת מעם ישראל שנתונים בשבי. הופעה של מעשה פדיון השבויים נמצאת בתנ"ך, למשל כאשר אברהם יוצא למלחמה להצלת לוט אחיינו שנשבה. על אף חשיבותה העצומה של מצווה זו, המכונה במקורות "מצווה גדולה", קבעו לה חכמים סייגים שנועדו להישמר מפדיון שבויים שיוביל לקלקול ומחיר כבד יותר. דילמה קשה זו נידונה ברחבי הספרות הרבנית לאורך כל הדורות, בה מקורות שונים אוחזים במחלוקת לשני צדדי השאלה.

description.en: The Hebrew term "mishloach manot" literally means "a delivery of portions," and sending them is one of the four mitzvot (commandments) of the holiday of [Purim](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/purim?sort=Relevance&tab=sources). One sends portions of choice foods to their friends on Purim, often in the form of gift baskets or bags of goodies, to contribute to the Purim seudah, or feast, another of the four mitzvot of the day.
description.he: משלוח מנות הוא אחד ממצוות פורים. "שולחים מנות" של מאכלים מובחרים לחברים בפורים, לרוב בצורת סלים או חבילות של ממתקים.

description.en: The [Mishnah](https://www.sefaria.org/texts/Mishnah) is the first major work of rabbinic literature, consisting of teachings transmitted over hundreds of years and compiled around 200 CE. It covers agricultural, ritual, civil, criminal, and Temple-related laws, presenting a multiplicity of legal opinions and incorporating occasional stories. It is a foundation of the Jewish oral tradition, which continues with the [Talmud](https://www.sefaria.org/texts/Talmud/Bavli), a work that is structured as commentary on the Mishnah.

[The Talmud](https://www.sefaria.org/texts/Talmud/Bavli) is the textual record of generations of rabbinic debate about law, philosophy, and biblical interpretation, compiled between the 3rd and 8th centuries and structured as commentary on the [Mishnah](https://www.sefaria.org/texts/Mishnah) with stories interwoven. The Talmud exists in two versions: the more commonly studied Babylonian Talmud was compiled in present-day Iraq, while the Jerusalem Talmud was compiled in Israel.

description.en: Nature is discussed throughout Jewish literature in a variety of contexts. Many Jewish sources point to nature as a manifestation of godliness on earth, while others describe the importance of caring for our surroundings.
description.he: בספרות היהודית הטבע מופיע בהקשרים רבים. התבוננות בטבע מביאה להכרה בפלא בריאת העולם וביופי שבו. היהדות עוסקת בקשר של האדם והטבע, כאשר מצד אחד הוא כובש אותו ומצד שני שומר עליו. כמו כן, המקורות ספוגים בתיאורים ובדימויים רבים מעולם הטבע כמו: אפיקים בנגב ואייל עורג למים בספר תהילים, פריחת האביב בשיר השירים, משל האטד בספר שופטים ומשל הכרם של הנביא ישעיהו.
